reviewText:
Early Access Review

Factorio is definitely one of the best base builders I've ever played. My estimate is that I have over 100 hours of playing Factorio before it arrived on Steam and it's still very fun and challenging. With procedurally generated maps, good mod support, adapting difficulty and constant dev updates, there's always something new to try and do in Factorio. If you're the kind of person who loves logistics management, designing functional bases or figuring out optimal designs, this is definitely a game for you.

I believe it also has a free demo so why not give it a try if you're intrigued?

The good stuff:
So, what makes it so special? The answer is simple - it has a perfect balance between micromanagement and macromanagement. In most sandbox basebuilders the early game is the best part - you're constantly challenged by hunger, resource scarcity and enemy strength. In a few hours though, when you improve yourself, enemies become a joke and gathering resources is only a boring chore, with no end in sight.

Factorio turns this dynamic upside down by enabling you to automate almost everything. Even though you're expected to micromanage your resources and defenses in the beginning, very soon you can devise systems that do this for you while you focus on macromanagement - expanding your base, improving your supply lines, bolstering defenses. You don't have to manually dig coal or iron - you have automatic drills for that, you only need to make sure you have enough electricity so they keep working! You don't have to automatically transfer dug iron to your furnaces, you have conveyor belts and inserters that do that for you!

Basically, very soon you become the boss, the architect - your only job is to expand production, advance your tech tree and keep up with the constantly evolving enemy. The bigger your base becomes, the more pollution it creates. While this doesn't bother you, it definitely bothers the local wildlife - depending on multiple variables (like global pollution, time passed, number of destroyed nests), they become more and more aggressive and evolved. They start to migrate, their nests increase in size and new kinds of enemies start to appear that will force you to shift tactics, maybe even go on the offensive and clear out some of the dangerously close nests.

The tech tree is very extensive and there are many moments when a new techonology completely revolutionizes your factory. For example, unlocking trains completely changes the game if you decide to use them. I've spent countless hours on building complex railroad networks with automated trains that deliver raw resources to my main base. You can make it as simple as one railroad with a 2-way train that delives a resource or you can have multiple delivery points, dozens of trains, roundabouts with signals to prevent crashes, automatic unloading mechanisms, train refueling stations, redundancies to prevent deadlocks... Your imagination is the limit.

And this is just one of the examples - when you add flying robotic drones, vehicles, power armor, automated construction, the game becomes even more interesting. In the late game you will feel like a god, building outposts with only a few clicks of your mouse, and it's always satisfying to just sit back and watch your factory work, no matter if it looks like a clockwork mechanism or like spaghetti.

The bad stuff:
There is one major thing that might turn some people away from the game - it is really a pure sandbox. Even though there's a victory condition (building a rocket), it's very arbitrary and ultimately pointless. The game is really fun when you set your own goals and work towards accomplishing them but if you're used to games guiding you by hand, telling you what are you supposed to be doing next... you're gonna be confused and bored in Factorio. There's a campaign that serves as a tutorial, and we're eventually getting custom scenarios / challenges made by devs.. but for the most part, you're left to your own ideas in the endless sandbox mode.

I also want to criticize combat. While it works well for defensive gameplay, attacking and destroying nests can be frustrating at times. In the late game your character can be killed extremely quickly so the best strategy is to just spam drones and explosives while running away from them, and loading the game if you get cornered and killed... or just build turrets close to nests and lure the horde into firing range. I believe the devs said they are going to rework combat eventually so this might not be true for long!

Conclusion:
Factorio is a sandbox basebuilder where your base is an actual defensible, functional entity rather than something you build just for aesthetics, or out of boredom. Rather than forcing you to do all the manul chores, you're in charge of building automated systems that do all the work for you. It has good graphics (stylish 2D sprites), performs good, has stable multiplayer, excellent mod support and receives constant updates by the devs. Even though it's labeled as Early Access, it might as well be released as a finished game and I wouldn't complain - it's working great and has plenty of content, especially considering its price.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Warning: Factorio is extremely addictive. The more you know, the more you want to know. The more you play, well... you get the idea.
This game is for people who want to settle in for the long haul - no such thing as a quick game, but make no mistake, every day, hour, minute and second will be filled with something to do. And then redo, when you figure out a better way of doing it.

So what is Factorio? Essentially, you just need to launch a rocket with a satellite after landing on an alien planet. But you don't have a rocket, and you don't know how to build one. So you have to build research labs, and provide materials for research, but you have to gather those materials. To gather those materials you need mining, smelting, and other equipment. To make those? Well, you start with a pick-axe and work your way up.

Simple, right? Well, no. This isn't your planet. In fact *you* are the alien, and all those factories you're setting up are causing pollution, which the native inhabitants don't very much appreciate. So much so that they will seek you out, hunt you down, and put and end to your day and your factories. So you need to defend, to attack, to improve your military capabilities. You need to decide what's most important to research, and where to expand into, what to build, when to upgrade, and how to move the resources around. And there's limitless ways of doing it.

Need a hand? Bring a friend! Factorio has multiplayer. While it's still being improved, it's very playable (providing you have a good solid connection). Work together (or against each other) to build the best factories, learn new techniques, and show everyone what you're made of.

Factorio has elements of Minecraft/IndustrialCraft, and for players of RimWorld, and Prison Architect, it's a must have.

The devs are keenly responsive and deeply care about the community, the forums are active, the game sees weekly progress reports, and frequent updates to fix bugs. There's a plethora of mods, and modding support is fantastic (even the base game is a mod). DyTech and Bobsmods alone will extend the playing life of the game by a huge factor.

Since the game is in early access, and at this time hasn't been released, it's unfair of me to post criticism.
If you buy the game, know that you are getting a very solid game right now which is completely playable and will give you many more hours than AAA titles. You will also be supporting an already solid development team, and more and more improved updates will come more and more frequently (as has been demonstrated by the hiring they've done).

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ah, ah, ah, what a wonderful world we sometimes live in!
This, my fellow gamers, is one of those true indie gems where you can actually feel the love of the developers.
I have played a tremendous amount of tycoon/simulator games in my life and this piece takes me right back to simcity 2000 and themepark. That same nostalgy and sense of boundless enthousiasm only kids and teenagers experience, thats what Factorio does to me.

It has a lot of depth, the amount of building and research is great with some intricate and surprisingly fresh takes like the Roboport and Blueprints and what that means for base development.
It is superstable, running at 60fps constantly, even in multiplayer, with no gamebreaking bugs detected (only a very few smalltime things that are easily fixed).

It is an early access which means it isnt finished. Something that is noticeable endgame, when all that there is left is killing alien camps for artifacts to continue research and development. This is the point where the game gets in abit of a  slowdown and a bit tedious but by far not enough to stop me from trying to achieve the ultimate goal.
I am looking forward to what the devs are planning to add and seeing how they have been working on this title for 4 years i am pretty confident it will be good.

All in all i can safely say that this is one of the best tycoon/simulator games i have ever played, its right next to Cities: skylines and Prison Architect.

Strongly recommended for afficionados of this genre, it has abit of a learning curve so beginners (and even more experienced) might need a youtube tutorial for certain aspects of the game.


Dont miss this title, triple A games eat ♥♥♥♥ when indies like this come out.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Factorio is a game that shows a lot of promise. It's also a game that already has a lot of good content, good game mechanics, a big, interesting research tree and a rather unique method of researching technologies.

There aren't many games I can honestly say are both currently very good currently, and have a lot of promise to become even better. This is a definite recommendation for anyone interested in large-scale building and design, efficiency and transportation.

That being said, let's get a list of everything Factorio DOESN'T do right now.

Factorio is not an RTS in the traditional sense. It does not have AI units for you to command, you cannot issue direct orders to units to attack enemy bases (although orders can be given to construct things, albiet through a semi-complicated and late-game researched method)

Factorio is also not combat-centered. Yes, there are enemy alien bases that will send waves of attacking creatures after you, and yes you can build turrets to defend them, and cars, tanks, rocket launchers etc to go out and destroy those bases. But combat is bland, with higher tier enemies simply multiplying the stats of the previous enemies rather than adding new mechanics or new AI strategies. Somewhat counter-intuitively, left click is not used to fire, but rather spacebar. Similarly, the crosshair will stick to the nearest thing to the current mouse position and holding down spacebar causes the player character to fire at maximum speed. This, coupled with the extreme high speed the enemy aliens move at, makes combat somewhat linear and uninteresting as early game strategy devolves into holding down spacebar until either the aliens or the player is dead, and lategame it's more about spamming follower combat robots as damage multiplication.

Advanced technologies, particularly things like nuclear power, a proper satellite system, electric trains, flyable vehicles, and pollution control mechanics, are not in the game.

That being said, I still recommend the game. Here's why.

Factorio is fun. This is a super simple one, but it's also one of the most important. What Factorio does do it does very well. Factory building is fun, intuitive and has a learning curve fit to the person playing it. A factory can be as simple or as complex as the player wants, and offers players a lot of freedom in how they want to set everything up.

Factory building is well balanced. A perfect foil to the imperfect combat mechanics, the balanced and interesting factory building is engaging and allows for an almost infinte amount of expandability to any design.

The game is deep, and takes a lot of time, but is not slow. When I say slow, I mean in terms of waiting. There have been very few times when playing factorio that I've found myself waiting for a lot of time for something to happen. Things in Factorio definitely take a lot of time to shape up, but the reason the game doesn't feel slow is a large supply of things to do. There's always expansions to make, walls and turrets to build to protect from attacks, and enemy bases to go out and stomp.

All in all, Factorio is a game that is currently good, and can be even better, given enough content updates. The devs have been very active and show no signs of slowing down, so I'm optimistic.

All in all, I'd give the game a solid 8.5/10.
Pros
Good design, robost factory mechanics.
Scalability, many ways to play, large number of things to do.
Game is fun. Very important.Cons
Annoying combat mechanics.
Boring and simple enemy progression.
Missing a few mechanics and technologies that would make the game wider.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

FACTORIO (Early Access)Disclaimer:
This Review shows my personal opinion about the game. NOTE: English isn't my mothertongue, so please excuse any language errors I make in this review.

The GameI'm playing this game now for about 2 years and so far I haven't encountered any gamebreaking bugs (at least not in the experimental/unstable channel). This game is about creating your own Factory using Mines, Furnaces, Transport Belts, Inserters (little cranes that put items from the ground/containers/belts to other ground/containers/belts), Assemblers, later Trains and even later in the game: Drones (like inserters, but not bound to the location).

You're having very slow start with a coal drill (drills ores using coal) some iron plates and a furnace: Barely enough to get started. You gather resources to create more furnaces and drills, so you don't need to gather all the resources by hand. Now you have to walk between your 2 - 3 mining sites to get your stone, iron and copper and to put new coal into the drills and furnaces. You start building a centralized storage and refueling system for your drills furnaces and resources. You still need to craft everything by hand.

Time for some research!
You build your first Steam Dynamos to get electricity and replace your coal drills with electrical drills. Now you build a research facility and research Automation I! You get assemblers! Assemblers craft items for you. e.g. 2 iron plates to 1 iron gear and with another assembler 1 iron gear + 1 copper plate => 1 research pack. Now you have automated your basic research! Yippie!

Up to this time you may still have encountered the first enemies which you had fight of with a simple pistol! Let's research turrets, automate ammunition production, research walls and create a defense line. Now you're pretty save from those biters ... at least for a while. But as time goes by your resources are all used in your factory; You need to find new ore deposits, then transport the resources to your base and hope no biters attack your new outposts.

Later on you get the trains (which can be automated ... what a surprise) with these you have access to even more ore deposits. you know have resources, 90% of your crafting automated and no more space. you'll need to clear of those Biter Bases. Once done you can finallly research the technologies to build a space rocket ... Now you *just* need to build a rocket ... Tada you've finished the game ... if you're fast in about 5to 9 hours. if not in about 100 hours.

In my singleplayer world I have a small factory and about 30% automized of what i wanted to automized ... after about 50 hours of playtime (on this world)

Pros+ Fitting graphics
+ Very good optimized (doesn't need much RAM/CPU/Graphics/Disk Space)
+ Nearly bugfree
+ Nice community
+ LOADS OF CONTENT
+ BIG Modding community
+ Devs who care
+ Stable Multiplayer
+ Good Balancing of difficulty (hard, but not too hard)
+ Still getting more content

Cons- if you're not smart enough for this game you'll fail with no mercy!
- Too cheap


Greetings
Pingger

Great crafting system

Cars and dense population of trees don't mix

Shotguns and Tanks are great lumberjacks
You can never have enough Electronic circuits...never


Side-effects can include but not limited to:
Trying to automate your RL job.
Having belt dreams
Frequent loss of time
Talking to other people about red and green science

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Another indie classic that puts AAA developers to shame.

Ok the bad first.

1.  The UI is pretty awful and needs a lot more work.
2.  Some information is not displayed such as maximum possible capacity for networks, which should be added to the electric network information panel.
3.  It will suck up your life (in a just one more turn kind of way).

Those are the only real complaints after over 1000 hours put into the drm free version.  The developers have shown a remarkable desire to implement features suggested by their fans and a willingness to go far beyond the point where most developers give up working out bugs.

One of the best games in recent years from quite possibly the best developers.  Thumbs up.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Do you like over-engineering, complex puzzles, logistics, resource management and simulation games?
If so, you're probably German.

But that doesn't matter, as you'll probably also love this game.

In Factorio your ultimate goal is to build a rocket to escape the miserable planet you're on, but 99% of the fun is on the way there.

You've crash-landed on an alien planet which has foliage surprisingly similar to Earth's.
However, this planet is also covered in nasty bitey/spittey aliens, which tend to get very angry over an outsider polluting their planet to hell and back, which is actually pretty sensible.

These aliens just made the mistake of not having developed guns or any other technology for that matter.
Not your problem, go shoot them in the face. Or don't, I'm a review, not a cop.

This game includes:
- Fast-moving aliens
- Your power plants shutting down for no reason(usually because coal mines ran out)
- Spaghetti Factories
- Overproduction to the max
- Every hippie's worst nightmare: Smog. Everywhere.
- TRAINS
- Glorious 90's-styled pre-rendered graphics

On a more serious note: This game is in public alpha/early access and is therefore subject to change. There's a lot of content yet to come, such as space stations and other wacko things like spider vehicles and whatnot.

Check the official site / blog for more!

Go get it!

P.S.

I once played Factorio so much I got Factorio-induced nightmares and had to stop playing for a month or so. This game is no joke.


Version this was written for: 0.12.24

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Allow me to throw my positive review on the mountain of other positive reviews.  If you're the kind of person who gets satisfaction out of automating resource collection and production (and who isn't?), this is the game for you.  The first time I got a train network set up with multiple stops I felt like a god.  I've probably only seen 2/3 of the technologies so far, and it's already more game than I could ask for.  Even the parts of the game not related to production are fun - the combat is slightly simplified but it allows just enough control to be satisfying, and I love driving around in the little car to visit my various outposts.  On top of everything else, there are already hundreds of mods available for customizing your game or adding features you think might be missing.

Forget the Early Access" tag - you won't even notice (except maybe the bland options menu)."
voteText: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game tickles those nostalgia strings about old 2D Management games. The main goal is to expand your factory infinitely to launch a rocket into space (or just build 'till your computer explodes) in an infinitely generated world while fighting monsters and creatures (peaceful mode exists). If you were to ask me, the biggest monster to fight is tending to your ever growing factory. Why? Well creature combat is as easy as pressing the Space bar (Literally xD) and factory management will test your exponential planning skills since leaving things unattended will cause things to clog and be unefficient at producing materials. That is where this game shines, it integrated its building mechanic into its strategy mechanic, with little to no confusion on how to use anything or how to use the tech tree. When I first started this game, I had no idea what to do, but with a few hours in, everything just fell into place like icing on the cake. This game is a game that puts you in the hotseat, makes you do a job, in which you enjoy doing, and you actually learn something from it to use on the next part of what you'll create. Learning on the job is fun in its own right but even I can say that I've had inefficient builds, clogged up conveyor belts, and have monsters ravage me and my base. Did that stop me from playing even if it takes time and dedication to get yourself drowning in materials? Nope. this game is too highly addicting and mezmerizing in its own right, it made me want to improve and learn more, like a good strategy game, failure comes with its own reward, knowledge and experience.

Overall, this game will forever remain on my favorite games list in my library, even with the ever growing gaming industry I find myself coming back to the good 'ol 2d factory builder (It shows only around 2 hours of gameplay as I write this review since I play offline most of the time). This means a lot, not just to me, but to what games are today, Not about the fancy graphics, but the gameplay itself. I even bought the Soundtrack DLC as well, not just to show my gratitude, but because the music added the right atmosphere to the game, the feeling of being alone, no companions or pets but just you and your trusty brain to build to the 2d horizon.

Early Access? For 4 Years? Talk about dedication for a game that'll make my history books. Keep up the work Devs. You have my support (virtual pat on the back) all the way.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's one part SimCity, one part Dwarf Fortress, and one part OpenTTD.

Needless to say if you like any of those, you're probably going to like this too.

Though it may be billed as early access, almost all of the groundwork is already done, the game is already more or less complete and can only get more complete.

Graphically the game isn't all that impressive.  There's some jankiness to some animations, and the world is rather bland visually.  There's not too many different types of terrain, not that terrain makes that much of a difference.  The graphics are just there so you can tell different things apart, pretty much, and for that it accomplishes it's purpose.  Even though the graphics aren't that impressive in themselves, seeing the way your factory moves and works together is always a treat.  The zoom level being alterable on the fly is amazing, and it's actually useable zoom compared to what you'll find in a lot of variable zoom games.

Sound and music are more suiting ambience for a factory theme.  There are touch pieces of music that will mostly stay in the background and not irritate you.  That's pretty much what you want from this type of game anyway.  Most of the buildings have appropriate sound effects which is a nice touch.  Accumulator's buzz while charging, assembly machines have pleasing 'Ka-thunk's to them, and so on.

Obviously the meat of the game is in it's gameplay, and how wonderful it is.  It's a game of constantly expanding scale.  As you go on you get faster and more efficient at doing more and greater things, but you need to keep two steps ahead if you want those greater things not to crumble before your eyes.  Your resources don't last forever, you need to expand, expanding takes resources.  You need to be reaching out before it's too late.  There are always easy ways to transport goods huge distances, but the more expansions you make the less attention you can give to each.  You need to plan them to fend for themselves, because you'll have other things to deal with.  Five million other things, and if you solve one, three more things will appear.

You have a vast, infinite and expansive world to build your factory, but somehow you'll always be faced with difficulties trying to find space.  You need to connect resource A to Factory B, but Factory C's connection to Resource Y is in the way, and there's pipes from Resource K where you want your line to go.  If you don't want your factory looking like a spaghetti nightmare, you need to keep organized and manage your space well.  New resources and available goods will always add new difficulties in trying to hook everything up.

The enemies live on the frontier, making you think twice about expansion.  The game tempts you to sit on that iron until it's gone, but this is folly.  You'll learn where and when to expand, how to do it, and how to deal with the enemies you face.  The more you pollute, the stronger and more numerous your enemy, and the sooner they will be upon your doorstep.  The existence of hostiles makes tension from an infinite land, you try to remain tight as possible to reduce your footprint creeping up to the enemy bases, a delicate balance of clunking machines.  It's actually kind of brilliant.

The enclosed campaign mode is quite short, but it eases you in most of the game.  I hope that this section will be expanded before early access is over.  The last campaign mission ends with you having only maybe half of the tech-tree unlocked.  The later stuff definitely could use scenarios too, because the later stuff is game changing and can be a headache in itself.  This is where things can fall apart, as the game does not always give you all the information that you need to advance.  While it's in early access, expect to look to wikis, forums, videos and the like to get the basics down.  Once you UNDERSTAND everything that's available to you (which is quite a feat in itself), you'll start making better decisions, better factories.

If you like building games, If you like sandbox games, if you like sim games, don't hesitate.  Get this.  You'll love it.

If you like games that make you use your brain, definitely, there's enough teasing and conveyor belt puzzles in here for days.

It's an amazing enough game to convince me to write my first Steam Review, and I know there may be thousands of others saying good things, but I felt it important enough.  We need games like this, we need MORE games like this.  There are things that could be more fleshed out, but this is an absolute 100% recommend from me.

reviewText:

well here is the breakdown

1. spawn on a fresh map... tons of resources available to me

2. start setting up base

3. got a few visits from the friendly locals... (pumping lead into their shells lol ! )

4. expanding and remodeling the base

5. needing more resources but none in general vacinity... ok, set up outposts and transfer everything i need back to main base with the use of multiple trains

6. Bots minions to do all the leg works from point A to point B... FANTASTIC !!!

7. locals getting very angry with me and evolving ... taking out some of my valuable outposts... time for retaliation !!!

8. lazer turrets are your best friend !

9. pushed back bugs far enought so they dont delay my Rocket silo production

10. have a last look around at all the work i've done to get to the last precious point in the game

11. probably the most satisfying moment of the whole game... placing the satelite on the Rocket and launch it into space !!!


Now... i have spent alot of time on a lot of games... and with the whole tedious resource gathering in this one... It was so worth it !!!
Loved every second of Factorio, you would never think it right off the hop at first glance, but there is way more into this game then you think.  so much designing, researching, bug extermination. the biggest thing i find that really sparks it all up. there is a definit sence of responsibility. The bugs are very unforgiving and will try every way to kill you... and once you die, its game over. No respawns if you die. 1 Life, 1 missions. survive so you can get off the damn planet !

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I bought Factorio a very long time ago. Even back then it was a fresh and unique idea to build your own factory. The first few moments I've played I knew I will love this game. It's probably best described as kind of a puzzle adventure action strategy simulation.
There is so much content, I'm sure it will take a many days of your precious life until you discover and build everything Factorio has to offer. The game is about managing your transport belts, so you can get everything where you want to have it. The game is about creating a network of materials and advanced products, e. g. the third generation of science packs is incredibly complicated if you don't have any clue about everything works as the game is also about the joy of figuring out how to accomplish certain things. I remember being very happy when I've finally figured out how to let drones place your solar panels automatically with a blueprint.
Although admittedly the game can be a little scary at first considering the amount of content included, Factorio is ten (or even a hundred times) more satisfying and rewarding. There are no obvious bugs to be found since the devs put so much effort in bugfixing it's almost unbelievable. As far as I remember every major version has been being checked for even the tiniest and nastiest bug for weeks - or rather months. All machines, trains, resources, transport belts, trees - everything - look just beautiful. If you can't see the love put into this game here then you are probably a lost cause. lol
Seriously, if you have a soft spot for either puzzlers, adventure, action, strategy or simulation games I can highly recommend this gem. You will get so much content for its money, Factorio certainly doesn't need to hide behind the one or other AAA game.
Oh, did I mention it even has multiplayer?

Also, make sure to read about the whole development process in the Factorio blog[www.factorio.com].

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Do you like building a base, and defending it while collecting resources? Then get this game, because this is the best base building game there had been in a long while, if not ever!

It's called Factorio because it's based on the idea of building a factory, but like many RTS games, you have to obtain and manage resources - building one thing that leads to another, and then another, while defending yourself on an alien world.

But it's the way that you go about this that is so compelling about this game, and that's where the factory bit comes in. And basically you are building a factory, a factory where you have to intrically manage the distribution of every resource you collect, there is nothing abstract, you see it all, on conveyerbelts, in storage boxes, in your production machines, or in your personal storage. It is, therefore, a clear, closed logical system, which you have to manage, and where you can see and manipulate every single element.

This is the games strength. More than any other game I have played, it satisfies the itch to manage a logistical system, and make it as efficient and beautiful as you possibly can. Add to that the fact that you have to defend this againt hostile creatures, and integrate a system to do this into your base, and you have a very satisfying and addictive game.

The game includes:

* Tech tree - you have to make the resources for research
* Walls, turrets and gates
* A railroad system for getting resources from outposts, including signals and schedules! You can get in the trains!!
* Total control over the layout of a massive system of conveyorbelts
* Automated systems of stock control and resource distribution
* Direct fuel, electricity, and solar power
* Combat, featuring self-powered armour and portable shield and lasers
* There's even a logic circuit system in the game that you can use to do pretty much anything
* So much more it would take pages to describe

There is no better game for designing a system of bases to manage resources and achieve goals while integrating a defense system, not that I know of anyway, and I have played most of them. If you like RTS or resource management games at all, this one is a no brainer. It's got the highest ever Steam rating for a reason - it's that good!

Oh and the fact that it's in Alpha is a red herring, there is more to enjoy here than most completed games (absolutely no exaggeration), and I have never had a crash or seen a bug once.

Buy it!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After having been a member of Steam for over 5 years, this is my very first review. Though not important to the review itself, I am attempting to express how sure I am that I love this game, and to express to the developers how much I appreciate the tireless efforts they have made and will make to ensure that their product continues to grow and improve. Over more than a year, I put many hours into Factorio before it was released to Steam. Here are my thoughts.

The game is complexly simple. Start with nothing and, with as few boundaries as possible, build something. The style is up to you, but the game mechanics is factory-based automation. For those of you familiar with MineCraft’s factory-style mods, the concept will be familiar, but the execution vastly distinct.

As you build up and produce more pollution, the critters start trickling in. It is possible to lose to their attacks, but that will probably only happen if you aren’t watching and they find a fatal flaw in your design (or power grid). So, don’t worry about this being a combat-based game if you aren’t into that. 99.9% of the attacks are thwarted by automated defenses, anyway, with only the first couple or so requiring the use of your personal weapon.

As I said, complexly simple. The goal is simple at this point, but how you get there is up to you. Build a compact base or a sprawling megafactory. Build railways far and wide or just to a few key points. You will have to expand some and you will always have to keep new expansions in mind, maintaining power and defenses. When you get to where you can end it, it’s your choice. Keep playing all you want, or move on to starting over.

I easily sunk over 70 hours into each map I played, though I admit my play style is slow and steady.

As for the cons of purchasing, there are none for me. I consider it one of my best random finds. If you want the flashiest graphics, you will be a bit disappointed. If you want a deep story, that’s not here. But, if you want to sink some serious hours into building something that has your unique stamp on it, and you like maximizing production line efficiency (including your own layout) while throwing in a dash of base defense and exploration, you may enjoy this game, as I have.

The small development team is still adding content and improvements to this title. Some things may change, but it’s already got enough that it’s worth the money if you think this may be for you.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ok, there's much to be said about this game, but I'll try and keep it short so you can play it earlier:

Factorio is a really great game, especially if you're into kinda management style games, that start easy and end up melting your brain. Repeatedly. Throughout a single session.

It does a great job at eating your time and rewarding you with a great feel of accomplishment as you grow your base, producing more and more goods of increasing complexity, making you redesign every part over and over as you unlock new technology and learn new tricks.

And all that with a very astonishing amount of polish even in this stage of development. In more than 600h of playing I encountered one (1) crash to desktop. One. In a session with 20+ mods. And just because I went ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and went so large I ran out of RAM. Upgraded RAM, problem solved. Until I ran out of RAM again, ~60h later ...

Conclusion: First game to make me upgrade my RAM, twice. And made me write my first Steam review.

Tl;DR: Would spend days after days playing it again. And will. And you should, too.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Definitely worth the money if you like sandbox building and managing games.
Starting simple and manual, your factory grows as you produce more and more things in automated assembly lines. The end goal is (currently) to launch a rocket into space, however to get there you must automate the production of headache inducing assemblies to get science packs for researching, while fending off the local wildlife and all the while maintain enough energy to run your base and try to maintain an idea what the conveyor belt spaghetti you just made is doing exactly. Of course with careful planing and generous space allocations one can avoid the problem of having to cram another two assemblers into an already tight space, having a mess of belts or fluids mixing in the pipelines and instead you have straight forward assembly lines that are extendable and dependable with straight belts and a minimal use of logistics bots.
There is a ton of mods available for all kinds of purposes and it is decently simple to write them yourself or modify existing ones to suit your needs. The only drawback is that there is currently no automated updating feature for mods, such as steam workshop and that some game updates may change the way mods need to be implemented, invalidating a whole bunch of them.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Let me start by staying that I've owned Factorio for just a few months before it got on steam.  I've probably put around 200 hours into the game outside of steam.

As a child I loved video games, I loved all kinds of games, from platformers to RTS games, and I remember as a child, I would always be sad when I looked at the time.  Where had it all gone?  It felt like I had only been playing for an hour.  But now its 10:00 and my mother would tell me time to go to sleep.  How had six hours gone by? Is the clock broken?

At some point while growing up, this feeling stopped happening to me, I would look at the clock, and not be surprised by how much time has passed. I knew how long I had been playing games for.  Though I never really thought about this feeling again, that is, until I played Factorio.

I remember, the first time I played Factorio, I told my friend I was playing it, and he didn't know what it was, however it was at that point he said to me Hey don't you have work tomorrow
date: shouldn't you go to sleep?"  At first I thought he was insane
recommended: after all it was only five in the afternoon
hoursPlayed: and I hadn't even eaten dinner yet
voteText: well that is until I looked at the clock.  It was currently 1:30 AM.  I had played the game and truly lost myself in it
helpfulPercent: forgot that time
votesTotal:
and even food existed.

This would go on to happen multiple nights afterwards.

This game is so addicting and fun

column19: or figure out how to do something better.  So many times I've looked at something in the game and thought to myself
column20: "There's no way I can do that! Unless..." and four hours later I have accomplished what I was trying to do
column21: not because things are tedious or take too long
column22: but because I'm desperately trying to figure out how to move my current setup to jam one more thing inside.\n\nThis game is pure fun
column24: there are very few games that truly absorb all my attention
column25: causing me to lose track of time.  This game is one of them
column26: and I would recommend this game to anyone."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Until now, I had yet to play a game which excites me in the same way as when I discovered The Sims franchise particularly 1 & 2). This says a lot because for me, not many games live up to those kinds of standards.

I absolutely love this game and currently I have only spent 4.4 hours in it. In that time I have learnt the basics which included starting a free play game, ditching free play game, re-starting free play game etc... It is SO MUCH FUN! This game gives you full control, your factory works the way you want it to, and there feels like endless possibilities.

The research aspect, while I haven't explored too much currently, is pretty extensive. I am just so excited to learn more and play more.

This review is pretty much just a first impression, and when I've sunk some more hours into it and understand everything more, I will probably construct a better one.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've been playing Factorio for over a year, and it has secured its place as one of my favorite games. In many respects, it is basically a puzzle game, in which you have to figure out the best way of getting many, many objects from point A to point B, when those paths need to criss-cross and collide and work around one another.

Your first few factories are going run into tremendous problems. But don't despair! And don't be afraid to try, try again. Each time you start, you'll learn something new. And remember: The solution is always more!""

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is actually pretty good,
I watched a few videos on youtube and decided to try it out.
However Do not play this game if you have something important to do....

Seriously,  I have this game for less than 3 days now and I already have over 20 hours of game time.
This game seriously eat your time away.

You start with about nothing but end up tweaking every single little details and times fly by as if there was no tomorrow.
I played about 16+ hours in my first playthough I haven't saw the time flying so fast in years.

It is a great game.

However, once you are near the end game. it get's a bit boring.
Id recommend playing with friends. ( I haven't got the chance as of now )  It sounds really cool.

It seems to be supported by mods. I haven't tried any yet.
Id recommend the devs to enable the Steam Workshop for mods. that would be great.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Oh man, this game is good. I guess it's sort of like a city builder, but the whole goal is to automate production of stuff. To build something really cool, you first need to build the components. To build those components, you have to build the sub components. To build those sub components, you need the materials. To forge those materials, you need to mind the raw ones and get them to the forges. Everything is connected and circular.

It starts off pretty simple and gets very detailed.

Play the campaign tutorial first. It will get you started.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI've been playing Factorio for two years now and the entire time it has been my favorite game! The simple game mechanics let a player start out with little practice, but it scales up as you become better and even with no mods I am still not bored after around 500 hours of playtime. I would easily pay $45 for Factorio instead of $20 and not have any regrets (apart from losing control of my social life) ;)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Factorio is a great, unique game, which offers engaging, creative gameplay despite its clear weaknesses. At it's core it's a game about logistic problem solving, that let's you finally create inspiring, huge scale factories, where everything just clicks and works.

It bears the fascination of inventing and creating your own working tools and also offers room for experimentation with its systems and design. The core gameplay is so entertaining and satisfying, you'll gladly keep on playing although you've already reached the end goal. Expanding and optimizing your factory, inventing better designs or just revisiting an older factory and looking what you've come up with is nice. Trying different ways to do things is nice. And doing everything very large scale is mostly fun, because the game's mechanics are carefully chosen to make the gameplay fun, demanding and motivating at the same time, for example:
Factorio offers tools to alleviate micro management. You don't need to place every thing yourself, later on you create blueprints of larger parts of your factory and can duplicate them easily. But to do this you need to create bots and you need to design your factorio in a way that copy-pastable and flexible. Designing blue prints is a nice little game in itself and allows very quick expansion. You get a nice transition from early to late game, while naturally being offered new challenges.

Other high points:
Factorio's mod support is great. You can add a lot of stuff and it isn't that hard to do.
It's highly optimized. Your factories will get VERY huge, before you notice any fps slowdown.
I'd like to discuss some of weak points of factorio:
repetitivness: While trying different builds is fun, an optimal solution is found after a while and there's no advantage in getting creative after that. It's fun, but the game doesn't reward you. If you're not the kind of player, who can reward himself or likes to put challenges on himself you might get bored after 2-4 factories or feel the need to try mods.
underused Systems: the train system and the logistic system are both interesting and fun to play around with. The problem is that they're not needed in the core game atm. Trains are more expensive to set up and require more effort to organize and expand. They're still great fun to play around with. It's more obvious with the logistic system. You can coun't items, make some parts of your factory work depending on some inputs etc., which is nice to toy with but ... unnecessary. You don't get any real benefit from using those systems. The game is fine without them, so it's not a big deal, but it feels slightly wrong having those great, but somewhat useless tools.
Combat is weak! It's a nice early game pressure, forces you to spend resources to defend your base and makes exploration a little risky (not much). In the mid-game it's mostly tedious and is certainly the most unfun part of the game, especially clearing biter nests becomes boring the second time you do it.
If you enjoy the trailer buy Factorio! It shows exactly what it offers and if the thought of creating a large scale automated factory sounds fun to you, you'll definitely find that in Factorio, it's executed very well!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Factorio is totally worth every single minute, second, hour, sleepless night, and heart jump when you are about to get hit by a train. You start with near nothing, and build. Build, build, and deliriously craft an empire.

Hours pass, and there are no regrets - only satisfaction at what you have made and the drive to do it again and again.

This game, after sinking 142 hours into it, is addictive, as it presses your mind to consider what steps to take next as you expand your empire... and your pollution cloud.

1000/10 would recommend. Especially for Engineers. And people who foam at the mouth at massive blue squares on the map. And people who like to use walls to write out text using pixel fonts on the map. And so on and so forth.

Just play the game - you won't regret it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Man This is excellent.
For those looking at some of the vids and  thinking it looks too hectic, don't Panic!!!  It can be hectic if you want it to be, but there are enough options when you start the game to set it up to be as slow or fast paced as you like.
You can turn off the enemy initiated attacks and make the playfield huge to give you time to learn. And there is lots of learnin to be had :-)
The complexity of your factories builds up over time so that helps too.
It always starts off with a lot of manual work, but its not long until you eventually automate it more and more. Don't be put off by the first stages where you have to dig and mine and stoke the furnaces yourself. It is not long before you get all that automated and you can start focusing on how to grow your megafactory and work out how to get the resources to where you need them.
You definately need to use the wikis and tutorial vids to get your head around some of the concepts. There are some very clever and efficient ways of arranging things that I just didnt even concieve until I watched some of the excellent getting started vids.
Dont be fooled by the early access either. This game has heaps of depth and I have yet to find a bugs or crashes.
What a wonderful time sink :-)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Factorio is a game in which you start with nothing and end up with a hell of a lot more. You start to mine coal and iron by hand, until you can automate that. Then automate the automated, and so on.

Be prepared to spend a lot of time going back to your earlier designs to remake them more efficient. And while doing that, get distracted by having not enough power, so you go and remake your power plant. And while doing that get distracted by that one line of iron which isn't full enough, so you go and place some splitters so you can balance that out. And while doing that, get distracted by.... You get the point.

As RPS said it: Show's over, building games. It's time to go home.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have a couple hundred hours in the game, and it's awesome.
The game is about automation. You do something by hand at first, then automate it, then automate the automation. You get a lot of headscratchers when you try to get more complex stuff to flow, you rebuild your factory, you redesign everything.
Then something goes wrong, you realize you don't produce enough red circuits, you examine the problem and realize you don't produce enough plastics, because you don't have enough coal because your smeltery eats up all of it.
Or your electricity goes out and you spend half an hour getting it back up by feeding boilers by hand.
Problems are complex, because there are layers and layers of systems built on each other, and you only notice that something is wrong when the problem reaches the top layer, and you have to peel them back one by one.

If you are a completionist, you can get a ton of fun just tinkering your factory, make it more efficient, find the perfect ratios, realizing golden rules (like producing copper cable only on demand).
But vanilla doesn't make you use trains and the enemies are very easy to fend off. If you want to use the awesomeness that are huge train systems, you really need to use some mods, like RSO. Then you will get another couple hours figuring out how to place signals and chain signals to not get deadlocks. Transport Tycoon players have an advantage here.
Other mods, especially the big overhaul ones make the game fresh for even seasoned people. You have to figure out new ways to make your factory work.

Then add multiplayer to the picture, and the social aspect makes the game fun and cool again. Sharing roles means you can concentrate on the stuff that makes you tick, leaving the rest to the teammates, the more twitchy guys can go clear enemies, collecting the alien stuff, while the more planner types never even touch a weapon.

All in all, if you want fast action, this is not your game. On the other hand, if you like to tinker and think about designs.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Like most people, I have been playing this game for more than a year before it came to steam. This game has everything going for it: it's a lot of fun, an easy-to-learn-hard-to-master philosophy, it is developed by dedicated people, there is a great community and plenty of mods.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game is bascially finshed since about a year at the time of writing. It is now on Steam early access and more polished than most titles on release.

The core gameplay is mining resources, constructing factories and eventually working towards automating the process. The experience is comparable to playing an incremental game, but a lot faster and with very enjoyable controls. It is deep and content rich and one of the few games where the mods are of a quality and depth that they add a lot to the game without breaking the core gameplay.

I've played around 200 hours of Factorio before it came to steam, alone, with a friends and in a group and the multiplayer fulfills the promise minecraft never delivered on for me that you can really build something amazing together with your friends.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Factorio is a game where you crawl your way up from picking up iron and coal from the ground with your bare hands to having swarms of heavily fortified laser-equipped murder-bots obliterate anything in sight, as trains deliver masses of ore and other materials to your sprawling complex of pollution-belching factories.

You'll show your friends your completed factory after 30 hours of playtime and spend 20 minutes explaining how ore flows through your factory and gets processed to rocket parts. In the process of doing so you'll see multiple inefficiencies and plan a new, better factory.

When you start the next map, your friend will see what you started with and stare agape into the abyss to which you have plunged. They will then try the game to see how far down the rabbit hole you really had to go in order to spend so much time on how an arm inserts into a factory. And the cycle will begin anew.
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I cannot recommend this game enough. I've put hundreds of hours since May 2014 into it, and I don't regret any minute of it. There's not much to say that hasn't been said in other reviews, so just this: Watch the two trailers. If you can't imagine yourself playing something like that, walk away. If you're intrigued though, buy it and never regret your decision. It absolutely delivers on what it promises, and it has a lot more to it than that.

Apart from that: one of the most helpful and friendly communities I ever encountered, a great developer team which listens to its community (and is absolutely anal about bugs; I am pretty sure you hardly encountered a game that ran as smooth as Factorio did in early alphas), full modding support, which means: if it's not there, somebody might have already done it. And the modding community for this game, while small at the moment, already did some really cool stuff! Mods are pretty easy to install by the way.

I think I should stop right here, else I won't find an end :) Buy this game, there's nothing quite like it!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I normally enjoy games with a staggering amount of depth but I was still taken aback by this game. The thing that gets me is that it is extremely accessible but yet still retains such a massive amount of functions and gameplay quirks. Everything functions and it's simple enough to where it's not overwhelming with only a handful of natural resources but the amount of creativity you can put into this is insane. The game is about efficiency and hence the game's mechanics are just that as well. Starting from old fashioned drills burning hydrocarbons manually and digging up ores by hand to eventually creating vapor power cycle monstrosities that belch out smoke and exhaust in synchronization to the belts feeding coal down the line to where robotic arms grab and place into the boilers which then funnels water to the steam turbines to generate electricity to then feed your new electric mines in an ongoing effort to automate everything, and I mean everything. Planning it all out and seeing it all work is a real joy, having to look around and fix mistakes and to really think about how to optimize the entire setup. But there are also bugs to deal with. It's an ugly planet, it's a bug planet. I am really happy that the development team is very on top of this game and constantly adding new features and mechanics as I think this could be something very very special. It's everything I always wanted out of a late 90's RTS ala Command and Conquer Tiberian Sun mixed with the open world building of Minecraft, but it does the latter extremely well.

Overall, a fantastic time sink with a huge array of researchables and building potential.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I bought factorio about a year ago, and I have to admit, I didn't play it much. I'm a bit of a perfectionist, and I like to think that I'm doing everything in a game, especially a resource-based game, to maximize my efficiency. That means I spent a lot of time looking at guides and people who really know how to play the game, instead of actually playing it. This week I decided I would break out of my old comfort zone and simply try to have some fun with the damn thing.

SURPRISE! It's a good game, it's a great game, even. But it does have a few flaws. A few more tooltips in the tech tree would be helpful, as would a simple addition of a graphical guide to explain transport belt mechanics in greater detail (both can be found in the wiki, but in-game would smooth some of the learning curve.

In short, abandon your need to min-max everything, and just have fun with the game. I am loving it so far!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

An amazing game about automation and managing the supply logistics of a futuristic factory on a hostile alien world. The true joy of this game is the sense of accomplishment one gets from setting up machines to build an otherwise complicated item in bulk, often in hundreds and thousands of units. Each step up is practically logarithmic, requiring many resources that get refined and folded back into themselves. It's strange to say, but the closest feeling to pulling this off is when you finally kill a difficult boss in Dark Souls- you are faced with a challenge that seems insurmountable until you chip away at it and figure out the quirks by trial and error, even if it isn't obvious at first.

You will go through 3 phases of thinking with each new challenge: What do I have to do, How do I do it, and How do I do it more better? Factorio will draw you in for hours as you make strides in automation and fix any shortages that crop up from your increased production.

The best TL;DR comes from a Reddit comment: I have to expand my base to meet the needs of expanding my base"."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have a couple hundred hours in the game, and it's awesome.
The game is about automation. You do something by hand at first, then automate it, then automate the automation. You get a lot of headscratchers when you try to get more complex stuff to flow, you rebuild your factory, you redesign everything.
Then something goes wrong, you realize you don't produce enough red circuits, you examine the problem and realize you don't produce enough plastics, because you don't have enough coal because your smeltery eats up all of it.
Or your electricity goes out and you spend half an hour getting it back up by feeding boilers by hand.
Problems are complex, because there are layers and layers of systems built on each other, and you only notice that something is wrong when the problem reaches the top layer, and you have to peel them back one by one.

If you are a completionist, you can get a ton of fun just tinkering your factory, make it more efficient, find the perfect ratios, realizing golden rules (like producing copper cable only on demand).
But vanilla doesn't make you use trains and the enemies are very easy to fend off. If you want to use the awesomeness that are huge train systems, you really need to use some mods, like RSO. Then you will get another couple hours figuring out how to place signals and chain signals to not get deadlocks. Transport Tycoon players have an advantage here.
Other mods, especially the big overhaul ones make the game fresh for even seasoned people. You have to figure out new ways to make your factory work.

Then add multiplayer to the picture, and the social aspect makes the game fun and cool again. Sharing roles means you can concentrate on the stuff that makes you tick, leaving the rest to the teammates, the more twitchy guys can go clear enemies, collecting the alien stuff, while the more planner types never even touch a weapon.

All in all, if you want fast action, this is not your game. On the other hand, if you like to tinker and think about designs.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've been a supporter for this game since a couple of years back, before it went up on steam. A couple of years back I followed a rumor on a forum and go to see the trailer, and then for about 18 hours I literally could not stop thinking about this game.

I just HAD to try it. I couldn't really afford it at the time, but I HAD to.
So I bought it anyway.

I then emerged from my apartment about a week later, having run out of food and thus being forced to stop playing.
This game takes all the best parts from survival games and sim games alike (most heavily transport tycoon) and turns them into pure crack cocaine.
Every time you build something your mind starts working on future plans on where to go next, and even before you've halfway managed to construct that you realize there's a better way to do it, and THEN after you've finally put all those elaborate plans into action and built your factory the way you wanted it and give it a look-over...

...you realize it's some sort of mechanical spaghetti monster from space, having landed on the planest nose first and splattered conveyor belts in a hadhazard pattern that literally makes no sense at all.
Except it does. Or rather, it DID while you were bulding it. You know exactly what each part of this overly complicated machine does and how it works, but with that last tech you just researched you realize you'll have to somehow pull this whole thing apart to fit the new stuff in, and you realize that it might actually be easier to just do it all over again.

So, you start over from the beginning, thinking that THIS time you'll anticipate all the pitfalls and make the machine perfect.

Even after restarting for the 12:th time you'll STILL come back for more, mind brimming with ideas on how to improve your next design.
And as you've finally put your best end-all, new and improved, iterated and perfected factory design into practice, you just quietly sit there and soak in the poetic sights of your latest creation. A new spaghetti of conveyers transporting goods in weird loops and excessive workarounds that only it's creator could love.

And what a thing of beauty, it is.
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Do not let my play time fool you, I've spent an ungoldy amount of time playing this digital heroin before it hit steam. Which if you can already tell, usually is a trademark of a good game.

Factorio is a game about automation, a subject very few if any games tend to build their core theme around. The general idea is you start out on a hostile planet with nothing but a few iron plates in your pockets, and from that you create a sprawling megafactory belching pollution into the atmosphere like it's the industrial revolution. This factory produces everything from small gear wheels to monstrous death tanks and beyond. This fuel for megalomania is achieved by creating machines to do the crafting and hard working for you; miners to do your digging, inserters to do your lifting, conveyors to do your moving, smetlers to do your smelting and assemblers to do your crafting. All the while enraging the natives.

The replay-ability, at least for me comes from the process of streamlining your factory. The first time you play, your base will most likely be a total spaghetti mess with conveyors overlapping conveyors overlapping everything else in a glorious logistical disaster. But as you play new files you'll gradually make the process more efficent and more clean which then snowballs into expansion, in short, this game is perfect if you love hoarding resources as efficently and cost effectivley as possible.

For an early access title, it's one of the most amazingly well done games I've had the pleasure of playing for a long time and is well worth the money, though a word of warning; If you have a life or upcoming deadlines, don't buy this game because it'll suck the play time right out of you.


TL;DR checklist

The Good:
- Fantastic gameplay
- Little to no bugs or errors
- Lovely graphical style
- Wonderful soundtrack
- TRAINS
- Did I mention TRAINS?!

The Meh
- The end-game as of now may turn some people off, but if the idea does, hold out until later, they're bringing in space to the equation!

The Bad
- Trains can kill you when you try to high five them as they go past
- You can't pollute the world fast enough to roleplay a greedy capitalist

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I cannot recommend this game enough. I've put hundreds of hours since May 2014 into it, and I don't regret any minute of it. There's not much to say that hasn't been said in other reviews, so just this: Watch the two trailers. If you can't imagine yourself playing something like that, walk away. If you're intrigued though, buy it and never regret your decision. It absolutely delivers on what it promises, and it has a lot more to it than that.

Apart from that: one of the most helpful and friendly communities I ever encountered, a great developer team which listens to its community (and is absolutely anal about bugs; I am pretty sure you hardly encountered a game that ran as smooth as Factorio did in early alphas), full modding support, which means: if it's not there, somebody might have already done it. And the modding community for this game, while small at the moment, already did some really cool stuff! Mods are pretty easy to install by the way.

I think I should stop right here, else I won't find an end :) Buy this game, there's nothing quite like it!

Prepare to wreck your real life.

Pros:

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've been a supporter for this game since a couple of years back, before it went up on steam. A couple of years back I followed a rumor on a forum and go to see the trailer, and then for about 18 hours I literally could not stop thinking about this game.

I just HAD to try it. I couldn't really afford it at the time, but I HAD to.
So I bought it anyway.

I then emerged from my apartment about a week later, having run out of food and thus being forced to stop playing.
This game takes all the best parts from survival games and sim games alike (most heavily transport tycoon) and turns them into pure crack cocaine.
Every time you build something your mind starts working on future plans on where to go next, and even before you've halfway managed to construct that you realize there's a better way to do it, and THEN after you've finally put all those elaborate plans into action and built your factory the way you wanted it and give it a look-over...

...you realize it's some sort of mechanical spaghetti monster from space, having landed on the planest nose first and splattered conveyor belts in a hadhazard pattern that literally makes no sense at all.
Except it does. Or rather, it DID while you were bulding it. You know exactly what each part of this overly complicated machine does and how it works, but with that last tech you just researched you realize you'll have to somehow pull this whole thing apart to fit the new stuff in, and you realize that it might actually be easier to just do it all over again.

So, you start over from the beginning, thinking that THIS time you'll anticipate all the pitfalls and make the machine perfect.

Even after restarting for the 12:th time you'll STILL come back for more, mind brimming with ideas on how to improve your next design.
And as you've finally put your best end-all, new and improved, iterated and perfected factory design into practice, you just quietly sit there and soak in the poetic sights of your latest creation. A new spaghetti of conveyers transporting goods in weird loops and excessive workarounds that only it's creator could love.

And what a thing of beauty, it is.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Review of #Factorio:

In short - This game is the kind of game you can't stop playing, there's always one more thing you want to do and by the time you stop you realise it's been a few hours since you started.

When you're Sent from your home planet to find a new planet to mine resources from or colonize And the ship you're on  crashes on what you think is a deserted planet You find yourself with very little tools to start with.

Now it's your mission to start mining those resources that the planet has to rebuild your ability to send a satellite into space to communicate with your home planet in order to be rescued. you need to start by harvesting  wood and mining iron and copper smelt them into usable plates and crafts tools and machines to help you achieve that goal. along the way you will engage in research enabling you to improve your existing tools, craft new ones and more.

But, in contrast to what you were led to believe, the planet is inhabited by native alien life forms and the pollution you create with your technology and machines make them become aggressive towards you and you’re factories.So now you need to survive and to do that you craft weapons and other measures to fight back and hold them off.

When resources become scarce you are forced to forge a  railroad  and use trains with loading and unloading mechanisms to bring resources from far away areas called outposts. you also need to defend those outposts and maintain them.

This game is a combination of simulation / RTS/ building / management  / tower defense  genre game. it can be played as a single player game or a multiplayer game. it is an  angled above view, resembling games like Sim City, (Transport) tycoon games, minecraft (with Tekkit mod mod), Anno series,  dwarf fortress, Prison architect, Big Pharma. it has a demo with 3 missions and shows basic game concepts ( highly recommended) and it is very friendly to the modding community ( using  Lua). it also has an in-game map editor + Lua scripting and a dedicated server.

All in all it is recommended by me to anyone that likes this kind of games -  I have logged hundreds of hours playing this game since a very early release (0.10.8 alpha)  back in August 2014 and have not stopped playing it since.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've been playing this game for more than a year now and have hundreds of hours spent in it.

Factorio is a game where you have to build a rocket on an alien planet and launch it into space. To do so you need to research technologies and build factories that do the work for you. Everything in this game can be automated.

You start small by mining resources by hand but gradually unlock new technologies and buildings. You can build huge train networks, a logistics system with robots that fly around delivering items to other chests and yourself and a lot of different kinds of weapons, like a flamethrower, missiles, tanks, 3 kinds of combat robots and laser turrets which you will need, as the natives (called biters and spitters) on this planet will try to destroy your base if it creates too much pollution.

What I like most about this game is that you can rebuild it anytime without the need to invest resources again, as removing a building just places it in your inventory and it can be placed someplace else instantly.
As soon as you have construction robots, you can duplicate parts of your factory or your whole factory by blueprinting with a selection box and place it somewhere else, which makes it easy to expand your factory without manually having to place things down.

The map is procedurally generated and infinite in every direction, also giving you the option to change ore/oil/enemy size, frequency and richness as well as starting area (how far away the nearest biters spawn) among other settings.
There is also peaceful mode, when activated the aliens will not attack you unless you attack them first.

There is an active modding community that has made a lot of useful mods like trains that automatically lay rail tracks, remote train control, mods that show you the remaining ore in your ore fields and complete overview over the logistics network. There are also several big mods that add faster and improved machines, new intermediate products so you need to rethink your factory and new technologies.

The devs are very transparent with the development of their game, they are posting some insight about the game and upcoming features every friday on their blog (Factorio Friday Facts) for over 2 years now.
They also listen to the players. When they announced a new entity (the Circuit Network Connector) required to connect a building to that network a few weeks ago, most of the players were against that change so the devs revised that idea.

If you're even a little bit interested, the devs have a demo on their website: http://www.factorio.com/demo/stable
which is a rarity for most games these days.

This game is Donald Trump Simulator 2016. Wanna know why?

You start with you doing things using you hands, and then you get more materials.

You use the materials to start to automate the work you previously did to get more materials.

You use those resources to research new topics so you can automate the work you had to do manually.

Then you use the resources to build transports to travel to new places for more resources.

Then you use the materials to automate building, so you NEVER need to move again.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Excellent game overall -- I'm enjoying the unique construction dynamics and the focus on player-built assembly lines. The one criticism I have is that in the main campaign the 3rd level (the one with virtually no resources where you must destroy all the colonies with what weapons you have) seems really high in difficulty even on 'normal' mode. Maybe I'm just not a hardcore gamer, but truth be told I couldn't beat that one without cheating (and believe you me, I tried).

I have a suggestion, actually. It struck me that with the story setting -- that you're a marrooned space traveler building his/her way back into space -- something very basic was missing. Shelter. Productivity's all well and good but even if you've got an infinite supply of freeze-dried space rations you're still going to want somewhere to spend the night or sit down after a while (speaking in-character, of course). I'd suggest a three-tier housing" solution:

-A low-tech wood and stone 'shack' that can be entered like a vehicle. While inside
date: the player's health regenerates more quickly (useful for recovering after enemy encounters).\n\n-A medium-tech 'bunker' that has a radar as one of it's ingredients. Better health regeneration than the shack
recommended: plus a large "sensor zone" around it that will pre-emptively alert the player when enemies are detected (serving as an early warning system for attacks). Needs to be hooked up to the power grid to function.\n\n-A high-tech 'command center' that is basically the bunker on steroids. Very high armor and a built-in weapon system. Independently powered (batteries and other power tech items would be ingredients) with high player health regen bonus
hoursPlayed: command centers are ideal for staking out new resource claims in dangerous territories. Could also have storage capacity to further enhance its usefulness.\n\nHope you like the idea!"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

What can I say about Factorio, well for one thing it keeps me busy when I play it. The graphics are old school but nice and smooth and it’s a great game all around but you may just have to play this one yourself to find out how much of a gem this game truly is. From the very beginning you start producing iron and coals to conveyor belting them to their stations advancing in technology and then building rails and locomotives to move goods from one place to another.

This is a pure sandbox game with no true motive, however it may seem that you can fight many aliens for territory, I have never tried that as I was always in peaceful mode. As you advance in technology you must run more and more machines, provide power to them with power lines and just go to town with building and exploring new techniques and logic systems to get the job done.

This is indeed a fantastic game with much life, little to no bugs, and to top it all off it is highly modifiable and multiplayer. Do take my word for it and pick up this title on Steam.
