reviewText:
Early Access Review

Factorio has been available as an early access game from the developer's website for.. I don't know how long. I bought it in 2014 and even then the game was stable and didn't suffer from any performance issues (aside from a short stutter of half a second while the game autosaved.) That issue is long gone becasue the developers have focused a majority of their efforts on preparing as bug free an experience as possible for the Steam release. It's worth noting that the devs have been responsive, extremely consciencous and dilligient about squashing bugs, and have generally been awesome. Performance improvements have been added over time that allow MASSIVE factories to be created without appreciable lag.

The heart of the game involves building an automated production system step by step. For a very short period you will need to manually mine resources from the earth and wave your magic space wand to create tools that will mine them for you. Those tools require fuel which comes primarily from coal as an early resource, which powers machines that mine resources, smelt ores and generate electricity. Electric tools run faster and cleaner (more on pollution in a bit) which allows you to more quickly build parts and machines, all the while researching new technologies that lead to more new machines and even more advanced technologies. Basically, you're climbing up the tech. tree so you can do more stuff.

As you progress your research, materials gathering and production capacity, you will soon find that your pollution output has annoyed the natives, and they will periodically gather and attack the structures you created, or attack you on sight if you wanter too close to them. Of course you're able to equip personal weapons and build automated defense systems, and automated resupply is possible for your automated turrets (which require bullets) and later, your own inventory.

Eventually you'll extract and process oil, build trains and flying robots that carry goods to you or your factory storage facilities, as well as build or repair structures. The latter type of bot can work from blueprints you create, allowing you to quickly replicate part of your factory with a click of the button.

As with most games like this the devil is in the details and you have a physical factory layout to consider, from mining resources, to smelting them into useable materials, to refining and combining them in various ways to create the multitude of things you will need to advance to the end game. The game becomes quite complex and you will find yourself reaching technological plateaus that may require you to refactor parts of your production floor in order to get the most efficient layout possible. In later playthroughs you will know what to expect and can plan more efficiently, but there are always new challenges and bigger goals to reach.

It is possible to create logic gates in game and do fun stuff with them, including starting or stopping parts of your factory for whatever criteria you want. Running out of rock? Stop making stone walls. Need more circuits? Turn that on until you refill your supply. Robots and trains can move materials around and keep things flowing efficiently, but the materials cost of robots can be high and your train system can become complex. OpenTTD users will be comfortable with trains in Factorio--newbies, you're going to face a learning curve.

Game mods include a set of tutorial missions, three types of custom scenarios and a regular game with no specific goals. There is also a map editor which allows you to create custom maps and scenarios. Scenario logic is accomplished via Lua scripts that are fairly straightforward. This gives you a variety of game play, including peaceful worlds with no (or passive) natives, or hell worlds that start you off surrounded by massive amounts of enemies and limited resources and space to work with. The choice is yours.

Oh yeah, there's multiplayer.

This game is awesome people.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A little disclaimer here; I've bought and played this game before it came to Steam, and thus I know a bit more about what I'm doing, so my review may be a bit biased. To start us off, I'm going to list the pros and cons of the game.

Pros:
+Plenty to do. I've played on a single world for a looooong time, and only got around 3/4 to 4/5 through the game. I've never felt bored, and always had something to do.
+Fairly easy to predict what objects will do. For those of you who've played games like Minecraft, the basic mechanics of the game should be pretty easy to pick up.
+Automation. No, I DON'T want to mine for the whole game. I'd rather build machines to do it for me, and even more to make it go faster.
+Flexibility. There's no 'correct' way to make your giant monstrous contraptions, but there's always a better way.
+Exponential Growth. Remember when you had just one mining machine and one furnace? Yeah, I don't either.

Cons:
-Music is kinda boring, and Sounds can and will become repetitive quickly. I recommend muting the music in general and using your own.
-The enemies just won't stop. They keep coming and coming, so you'll need to constantly restock your turret's ammo (up until a certain point in the game), or automate that which takes resources. It may give you something to do, but it's just too frequent.*
-You might want to look at someone playing this or the Wiki before you jump in for more of the advanced stuff. Otherwise, the tutorial campaign's got you covered.

A Bit of Both:
/Enemy progression. If you've built a radar, it will eventually show where the enemy pods are in red. This is where they are coming from, so if you destroy them, you can stop enemy attacks entierly. The problem is, this and a few other factors (including pollution) causes them spawn stronger enemies, meaning there isn't a correct tactic for dealing with the problem. However, this allows for a more flexible and changing experience.
/Research. Yes, researching is fun to do, but eventually it needs to be completely automated, and the difficulty of the recipies makes automatic research hard for some and slow for others. Still, this issue doesn't arise until green or blue research is required.
/Finate resources. This forces you to expand your base far beyond what it's original size was, but this type of thing shouldn't be artificial.*

*Settings can be used to alter this feature.

All in all, the game's worth the 20$ I paid for it, even in it's early access form. It is perfectly playable, and the only downside is the lack of enemy variety. The rest of the game could be sold as a full release immediately, and has enough in it to surpass most similar games's value. So if you're looking for a game with elements from Terraria, Minecraft, Command & Conquer (or similar RTS games), Steampunk, and Tycoon games, then Factorio is the right choice for you.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I love this game! I bought it off their website, so it doesn't show my hours played on Steam.

You'll build a huge factory with a major issue being getting resources from the output of one part of the factory to another. There are many different types of manufacturing pieces. And all of it needs to run on power.

It becomes a perfect example of what spaghetti code looks like, and organizing and thinking through more elegant designs is a major theme.

Carbon footprint is also an issue, as burning more coal eventually generates enough pollution to attract the local wildlife, which will tend to want to eat you and your lovely factory!

Driving the whole progression is the technology tree.  The goal is to build a rocket to get off the planet.  But the technologies take exponentially more resources to research, and building the resources creates an exponential complexity of your factory.  It will twist your brain into a pretzel!

Early Access Review

I would hate to compare this to minecraft since Factorio is almost an entirely different experience, But for the sake of argument for someone who has never heard of Factorio, Imagine starting off in minecraft collecting resources manually (that's basically where the similarities end) but almost immediately you drop that pickaxe and you start building drills and machines powered by coal or use water sources for electricity to collect resources automatically (coal, iron, copper) and conveyor belts and robotic arms to transfer them to either be melted or simply stored.

As you consume resourses faster and faster and as your factory gets bigger and bigger you and your creations are endangered by inhabitants in the planet that just want to kill you, and destroy your ♥♥♥♥.

Build turrents, make weapons, destroy the ecosystem, and suck the planet dry of every natural resource.

I can't stop playing, 10/10. The game does a remarkable job in teaching you the simple steps but the campaign is such a small fragment of the bigger experience.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've been playing this game since 2013 or maybe earlier.
So as you may guess, I am happy it's finally on Steam.
And since then it got much better.

There's something in it for everyone.
- Fine control over random generation of an endless map.
- You like to engineer complex systems and see fruits of your labour work? Come on in.
- You like trains? Well, look at that. Trains with purpose.
- You like to shoot some worms? Welp, better produce some power armor and poison grenades on your factories. They're tough.
- You just like to burn coal on a scale and ruin local ecology for the aliens? Choo-choo!

Also, multiplayer.
Also, modding community that has been working for years. I hadn't even try any mods yet. Maybe I will, when I'm finally bored with vanilla game.
It's for mac and linux as well.

And there's more to come, since it's still not final release.
Sure, I recommend this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I finished the game for the first time on version 0.12 so some changes may have occured.

This is one of the best games I've supported in 2015. It took me 1 month to complete, as a very casual player, for a total of 64 hours. And I feel like I didn't get enough, yet! Those hours flew away like crazy :D

Exploring is a little bit boring due to the barren/repetitive world and doesn't make much sense after a while if not for the resources. But that's fine, it's not an exploration-centric game.
Fighting is fun when using a tactical approach. Trying to have an action approach is near impossible, the aliens attack so quick you'll be lucky if you get even one shot at them! Turrets (like tower defense), kiting and things like that are the best choices and they're very fun.
Researching is also fun, but it would definitely benefit from a proper tech tree and some more descriptive text, with interlocking requirements and somesuch.
Refitting/deporting industrial sectors is also fun, there's incredible room for improvement, always!

What I'm working on sometimes is optimising the infrastructure, like using less space, less buildings, less buffers, and wasting less resources and time. I enjoy this a lot, it gives room to creativity.

The time factor is the real measure of success, it is possible to do everything if you have infinite time. But doing something quickly (not placing buildings faster, but ramping up production and efficiency) is a very different thing. Sometimes it requires a lot of work to get timing right without wasting speed modules on the wrong/useless places.

A better story mode would be great, the tutorial missions are somewhat scarce on the duration side, they're quickly dispatched. Luckily, sandbox mode has a lot of settings to keep interest up. But some more things would be nice.

This game scratched an itch I've been unable to satisfy in years. This is an amazing game that still satisfies after hours and hours of gameplay. It's truly brilliant and if you are a fan of managment/building/strategy games I would highly recommend you get it, and if you're not a fan of those I suggest you get it anyway and you'll learn to love it!

Also, the modding community for Factorio is huge, so go check out the Factorio forums if you want even more gameplay!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I won't do the independent zones of the game, instead I'll try and summarize what you're actually doing and why it's fun playing a very nastalgic looking game like this.

Summary:

You're a lazy piece of crap that decides to crash into a planet inhabited by giant bugs, and in doing so completely strand yourself with no knowledge of how to build a ship, even though you're an engineer and just flew one.

Back to being lazy. You're so lazy that you decide that creating a furnace will save your life. Well it didn't, but hey lets slap some iron in there because we're bored. Woah, iron plates, cool I'll just put that in my incredibly large pocket. Oh ok, a big a$$ bug is here, wonder wh- K my hand is gone, lets make guns and turrets and cranes and drills and conveyer belts and explode because you decided putting hot coal on oil would be a good idea.


In Factorio, you are an engineer who crashes on a planet with very little resources to begin with. Your ultimate goal is to fly the heck out of there before you're bug food, but you need to go through multiple technologic advancements in order to build a Rocket Ship. The tech tree, art, sounds, and gameplay all work so greatly together to deliver an old timey ps2 2000s feel, you just can't help but feel happy when playing.



Also, if something works....Please for the love of engineering, don't touch it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Been playing this game since long before Steam release and it's amazing.

If you don't start off on the campaign (something I haven't beaten yet,) you start on an alien planet with a gun, a few bullets, a few scraps of iron, a mineral extractor, and a furnace.  Your objective is to make a colony to welcome the future of mankind while, essentially, destroying the native residents.

You will pollute the world with your lovely little machines, how much is mostly dependant on how you play the game.  Building around a forest will help mitigate some of your pollution (for a time, if I remember correctly, trees will break apart from suffering too much pollution,) but also make base production a hassle and may require a lot of time spent manually cutting trees down to get to resources.  A desert/plains allows for the easiest in terms of base production, but also the worst in terms of pollution mitigation, as well as several other potential issues (namely, not being able to find enough wood.)  You can minimize your pollution via other methods as well, maybe manually mining everything you need (you're pretty hardcore if you do this,) and only using extractors for oil, and minimizing use of electricity to only times when you really need it.

Why so much on pollution?  The aliens will not only attack more frequently as the pollution spreads on to them, but they'll also absorb a little bit of it and become stronger for it.  Are they kicking your butt and preventing you from moving forward?  Try starting a new world in a different biome, or try turning on an option so they only attack when you attack them (or get to close!)

Have you finally beaten off the natives and gotten your colony to land?  Why not start again, with a different world generation??  Try for a different starting biome, or even try for a different setup!  Maybe this time you focus more on trying to get things going through trains, or using robots more, or trying to expunge the use of coal except when neccessary?  How about playing without a care to local wildlife?

STILL not challenging or indepth enough for you?  The game is still early access, and there are updates still being done to it.  I started playing the game around the 10.0 version about a year or so ago, and it's had quite a few updates since then.  And if that's not enough for you, there are tons of mods available that will not only add more depth and complexity to the game (something it probably doesn't need much of, but there's still a joy in doing it!) but also mods that make it harder, or change the playstyle entirely!  Some that I've been interested in trying out are the no-manual mining (except for trees, but I don't often manually mine things anyway) and no-manual crafting (they give you a factory that runs on coal in the start of the game.)

Most the downsides I've encountered are sometimes a very sketchy multiplayer setup, where it's sometimes hard if not impossible to get into a game with more than one person (haven't tested on more recent versions, so take with a grain of salt here,) and the fact that I normally have to go into the save file and erase the replay data to keep the file from being 40+mb to download to the peers (I think they may have fixed this, though? Last times I've played with a friend, the replay data hasn't been too bad.)  I also tend to turn off the sound for the game since I'm often listening to music or talking on Skype with a friend while playing, so I can't comment on those aspects.

Going along with the multiplayer, it's set up in a way that may cause frustration for those who just openly allow others to join their server, maybe even among friends.  Chests are openable by anyone, resources are often sent along the world via easily lootable belts, taking buildings down is done at the same speed regardless of who put it up, or how high tier the building is, a single broken belt/track may cripple an entire system, turrets only respond to alien threats, and all players are visible on the map, etc.  So someone with a trolly personality can easily screw you over and cause many hours of work to be lost.  It's also designed more for co-op play in this respect than PvP.  Not sure if the devs have any plans to change this, though, as I haven't done much research in that regards, since I don't like PvP anyway.

All said and done, the game is really fun and interesting, and leaves things for people to do, especially if you go in with more just yourself.  Someone can sit back and work on the base, while the other can go out and try tackling alien bases if needed, or just explore the surrounding area.  If a resource management, factory building, outpost/town/city defense game doesn't appeal to you, I'd recommend checking out the demo before buying, or just skipping the game over entirely.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Since getting this game, I have played it almost daily with my friend. It has got to be one of the absolute most addictive management games I've ever played. Its intuitive, it's new, and it's fresh. Think Sim City, but you're the only citizen. NOw imagine that you'll die without proper resources. What do you do? You industrialize. But as you grow larger, the aliens mutate and attack. That red haze on the map? That's  your footprint on nature. Sometimes, you can take a bargain--using say, solar energy, instead of steam engines, to generate power. But is it worth the time, when coal is so abundant? Really, you can screw yourself, or live happily in this game, based on one choice. It's fantastic, and I love every minute of my drones zipping back and forth making more drones, as I organize trains, for the sole purpose of making and transporting sulfur and plastic.
10/10, a fantastic game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Easily and by far one of my favorite games.  This game has existed for several years pre-Steam, so don't let the sudden release on here fool you.

===========================
PROS
+ Content-rich for an early access game
+ Easily over 100 hours of gameplay (in one run) in current state.
+ VERY replayable (please note above as well)
+ Actively updated with good, active versioning documentation (IE: upcoming updates, what's currently being worked on, etc)
+ Friendly community (on forums)
+ VERY responsive and active devs
+ Active modding community, which generates even more quality content
+ Common sense UI/Design approach (Things are intuitive)
+ Multiplayer functions with the non-Steam version of the game

===========================
Things to Improve on
= Modding API
= Some kinks with multiplayer (Versus modes, matchmaking, etc...)[13.0 update will contain these, 1-3 months away]

===========================
CONS
- Can have a difficult learning curve
- Easy to get burned out on single-player vanilla gameplay after a few runs
- Military aspects of gameplay seem a bit lacking -- It's a chore to take care of biters/spitters (enemy) and in the end doesn't really feel rewarding.
- (Sometimes) impossible spawns (IE: you spawn on an island, and the game ends there because you can't do anything.)
- Awkward ore spawning algorithm.
- No necessity for trains (see above. A mod (RSO - resource spawner overhaul) fixes this)
- Awkward train mechanisms (Such as inserter placements to add/remove contents, or the lack of a liquid carrying car (fixed by mod), or the lack of ability to fine-tune automated trains (coming in the next update))

===========================

Overall, for the obligatory blank-out-of-ten score, I'd give this a 7.5/10. It's a safe one to try as the devs show no signs of pulling what most early access devs seem to do these days (abandoning the game), so if you have a spare $20, an open mind, and a like for games such as big pharma, or similar strategy games, give this one a try.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI've been playing Factorio since 2014. When I saw it was coming to Steam, I knew it would be one of those successful early access games such as KSP, Prison Architect, etc. I didn't expect it to be this successful. If I had to summarize my experience with Factorio with three words, it would be Efficiency, Arithmetic, and Optimization. This game can be played in a multitude of ways. You can go all-in and calculate every production line and get all of the ratios to line up. Or, you can just let yourself be free and build whatever's needed. Theres one big satisfaction to planning out everything; it all looks satisfying seeing everything organized without any hiccups.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nOne thing I love about this game, and what keeps me coming back after hundreds of hours is how rewarding of a game it is.  It masterfully does what is very difficult to do in games these days: eventually the game will be working for you, and not he other way around.  The example of this is the late game construction and logistics robots, with these your factories will run themselves.  It does take some hard work to get there, as well as smart planning, patience, and you will have to purge some natives, but when you are reaping the benefits of a complelety automated astonishingly complicated factory, and sit there and watch it all move fluidly, its worth it.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis is a great game. I bought it long before it was released on steam, so I am more than happy to give it a review. This is like a really cohesive version of those technical mod packs for Minecraft that focuses on what someone interested in this really wants, pure automation. reviewText:
Early Access Review

First off let me start by saying Early Access is crap. I absolutely hate it since games never seem to leave it, are often left unfinished and we have wasted our money. That being said, I thoroughly enjoyed this game, its tutorial and basic campaign. With a map editor and random map generator, this gamehas infinite replay value.

Factorio is polished, well thought out and can get a bit crazy. Conveyor belts going in every which direction, producing stuff just so you can fight off an enemy that is fairly easy to defend against, but nearly impossible to finish off. Basically a production line from hell. Automated mining facilities give you a steady supply of resources which in turn are smelted, tweaked and tweaked again so you can build that badly needed laser turret.

I had no crashes to speak of and zero lag. I just can't seem to think of a down side here, unless the old school graphics is a turn off for you. Quality product.

EDIT: So after just a few hours of play (I jest.) I am still hooked. I now have a tank with quite a bit of ammo, a ton of logistics robots (late game robots that replace my conveyor belts making the game a bit easier, there are other factors to keep me interested) and an outer defense wall that seems to barely hold them off at every turn....

So what's missing? This game is so addictive that sleep is missing.

What would make it more addictive? ACHIEVEMENTS *rolls eyes*

I absolutely love this game.

Next up, trying out different mods.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Jay! It's finally here on Steam!

As you might have noticed, this game has a big, dedicated community already, as this game has already been in the making for several years before they brought it to Steam's Early Access program.
What's so nice about this is that the developers have already proven how serious they are about this project, and how they listen to their community's ideas and preferences.

Unlike many other Early Access games that are showing up on Steam, this game already has a toooooooooon of content and a fully functional multiplayer.
And you don't need to worry about this being a dying project, because the developers are so engaged with the community and are constantly putting future content ideas up for discussion that we, the community, can then comment on and come with criticism and ideas on.

I've spend around 100 hours in this game so far, both in Singleplayer and Multiplayer, and I can't remember the last time I was so incredibly hooked in a creation game.

I cannot recommend this game enough!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Factorio is the only game of this type that I have experienced and it might very well be it's own type of game. Therefore I don't know what to compare it too and will only say that it does what it does very well.

So what's the game about? It is a survival sandbox. You harvest a variety of ressources (wood, stone, copper ore, iron ore) to manufacture items, machines and buildings. Eventually, with these you are able to automate harvest of the ressources you previously had to manually gather. Everything in the game is automate-able, but, you'll have to carefully plan supply chains and layout of your manufacturing plant". So
date: how extensive can automation get in Factorio? Very extensive! You can buid automated trains that will follow a set-schedule to distant plants you'll have previously built to move around supply and feed your supply chains. For example
recommended: you import iron ore from a distant mining plant you've built and export machine gun ammunition to it so loaders/unloaders will automatically feed it to the defenses you've set-up over there. Why would you need defenses!? Well
hoursPlayed: you also must survive relentless assaults from the local fauna while trying to expand control of the land.\n\nVisually
voteText: the game isn't for everyone; The textures are quite pixelated but charming none the less and make for an enjoyable atmosphere if you aren't thrown-off by the 8-bit look.\n\nI found myself spending 12 straight hours to complete one of the earlier scenario the game has to offer. I am very excited to see what the more advanced scenario will have to offer."

I bought Factorio in Feb 2013 through Indigogo and haven't regretted it for a moment. I have 50-75hrs of bliss from this game. As a gamer that is a decent compliment, but as a developer who can't afford to spend more than 5-6 hours with any game evaluating what works and what doesn't ....it's either treason of prinicples or a compliment of the highest order. When I am playing a game for pleasure I am shooting myself in the foot and putting my financial future at risk so it HAS to be worth it. In this case it definitely is.

Well done Wube Software. Thank you for fun and for keeping the industry fresh and alive.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game has been playable for several years and I've been lucky enough to be apart of it from early on.  The developer is amazing, they work very closely with the community to insure the best possible gameplay for all and features that people want or do not wanted are properly implemented or removed.

Gameplay whys, this is a fantastic game, it is easily one of the best if not the best management game to date. It's gameplay is highly customizable with in game settings and mods if you so desire. It can be the most difficult or easiest game you've ever played depending upon your desire. This is a game that makes Civiliazation games look short, if you are trying to rush to the end, you are still looking at hours and hours of gameplay, but for the average player such as my self whom is not necessariliy interested in rushing, games last for a minimum of 40+ hours. Don't let my hours on steam fool you, I have multiple words saved that have well over 100 hours.

This game is very complex and in depth, it gives players the ability to build and manage how they want and players can make everything as automatic or manual as so desired. The community and developers are what most games dream of. If you have not purchased this game yet, stop reading and click Add to Cart then Checkout. Go Now!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Easily and by far one of my favorite games.  This game has existed for several years pre-Steam, so don't let the sudden release on here fool you.

===========================
PROS
+ Content-rich for an early access game
+ Easily over 100 hours of gameplay (in one run) in current state.
+ VERY replayable (please note above as well)
+ Actively updated with good, active versioning documentation (IE: upcoming updates, what's currently being worked on, etc)
+ Friendly community (on forums)
+ VERY responsive and active devs
+ Active modding community, which generates even more quality content
+ Common sense UI/Design approach (Things are intuitive)
+ Multiplayer functions with the non-Steam version of the game

===========================
Things to Improve on
= Modding API
= Some kinks with multiplayer (Versus modes, matchmaking, etc...)[13.0 update will contain these, 1-3 months away]

===========================
CONS
- Can have a difficult learning curve
- Easy to get burned out on single-player vanilla gameplay after a few runs
- Military aspects of gameplay seem a bit lacking -- It's a chore to take care of biters/spitters (enemy) and in the end doesn't really feel rewarding.
- (Sometimes) impossible spawns (IE: you spawn on an island, and the game ends there because you can't do anything.)
- Awkward ore spawning algorithm.
- No necessity for trains (see above. A mod (RSO - resource spawner overhaul) fixes this)
- Awkward train mechanisms (Such as inserter placements to add/remove contents, or the lack of a liquid carrying car (fixed by mod), or the lack of ability to fine-tune automated trains (coming in the next update))

===========================

Overall, for the obligatory blank-out-of-ten score, I'd give this a 7.5/10. It's a safe one to try as the devs show no signs of pulling what most early access devs seem to do these days (abandoning the game), so if you have a spare $20, an open mind, and a like for games such as big pharma, or similar strategy games, give this one a try.

I'm 30 years old and I though I was moving away from gaming. I just could't find any game that gave me fun enough. With factorio I have reinvigorated my passion for gaming, It has been at least 10 years since I didn't enjoy a game like this.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I first became acuainted with this game back in April 2014, after having watched Quill18 play it for a little while. It seemed like a really interesting and deep game that focused heavily on logistics and planning, and I fell for it right away. In a way this game can be compared to Minecraft. It's an open world game where the gameplay itself is the real attraction and a purpose unto itself, rather than being driven by the actual stated goal of the game (The End in Minecraft, as of writing the rocket silo in this game, though that will probably be expanded upon in future updates). The actual play mechanics of it is beautiful, and if you were the person wanting to build complicated redstone machinery, this game is definitively for you.

I believe this isn't a game that will appeal to everyone, but for the people who like the base building and resource management games this here is an absolute pearl, and you certainly won't regret getting it. Highly recommended.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Got this game last friday. the day after the release, and since them I have almost completed a day (24hours) of gameplay.

The game is indeed complex to play but easy to learn about. The brief campain mode is more than recomended to learn the basics. I have starter 4 freeplay sandbox games since finishing the campaing and each time I start a new one is because I have better ideas to make the factory I am building simplier and better oriented. There are a lot of things to research in the games as well as a lot to built which shows to me that I have only passed through the surface and no more.

As an early access game it does what is supposed to do, with having an incomplete brief campaign and not many modes but the sandbox is almost complete meaning that the lack of further levels does not have a huge impact in gameplay. I have to note down, a tiny downside, not all the buildables are explained by them self, as there is no description and it should be added in an upcoming update.

Nevertheless, I suggest this game to anyone who likes sandbox games with a sense of strategy and also some action during alien attacks, well worth the 20euros for the content and replayability.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game does so many things so perfect on so many levels that I feel like an idiot not hearing about this game sooner. In one sentence, if you like creating stuff while figuring out problems at every step of your production cycle, then this game is for you 100%.
Another thing to like it's that it's not an easy game but it's not a hard game either. It's not putting anything in front of you, but as long as you're applying brain power to your issues, you will figure out pretty quickly what you need to do in order to make it work. Having co-op is a godsend as you can spend hours with a friend or two trying to make it work better, more efficient, faster.

The game does have a game mode for playing normally with your character (which btw, if he dies, the game is over), which means you need to move your character everywhere you want to build/inspect/see. The other alternative is sandbox where you have no character, you can move and build freely, but it still requires you to build stuff manually before you can automate it. Personally I prefer the freeplay mode, with the character - somehow if doesn't feel detached at all and you're there, overviewing your entire process.

Recommend ? YES! You will lose hours trying to create your automatic processes while only scratching the surface of what you can do while at the same time trying to fend off the inhabitants" of the planet (thankfully
hoursPlayed: get a friend and start having fun while creating!"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Factorio is what happens when someone feels that the Technic pack for Minecraft was just a bit too confusing, which, granted, it kinda can be.

So, after a pretty lack-luster tutorial which I recomend you go through, you go into the sandbox, with the goal of eventually building a rocket home. That's it. However you go about getting home, is up to you.

Just like in technic you start off fully reliant on coal. And there's tons of it to mine up. Build the machines, that burn the coal, to mine coal. Build the machines that burn the coal to mine copper, iron, and stone, and set up convator belts that lead eventually to an ureliable grabber arm that carries stuff from the belts to a chest, or furnace. They work as they should and there is literally no guess-work.

You can set it up so that the miners mine up all the materials needed to create say, copper plates. And you can automate the entire process so arms load the furnace, and arms remove the product into a chest (save for refueling the miners and arms). But here's the thing, each arm will only load 5 of each material whereas you can go in and drop entire stacks in there (one stack is 50 of whatever ore). Is it a bug or is that how its supposed to be done? If that's how its supposed to be done, make it so it isn't, That's a dumb limiter.

If you have all the stuff needed to make, say, a steam engine, your dude will run through all the preliminary steps for you, making those recipes worthless on the crafting grid. An electric drill takes a handful of circuit boards, but you got all you need for an electric drill, so why are the seprate materials needed at all, if only to point out what will get consumed.

There are aliens but they're basically the zerg, and of course they don't like you.

I won't give it any breaks for being early access and I hope this menu mania of a game gets cleaned up because its such a delightful experince seeing things actually work for you vs techinc where I'm forced wondering what I did wrong.

Add more to it please, and please please please don't be a one trick pony. Please.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a game about automation. And part America Simulator 2015/2016

You put obtain wood, stone, coal, iron ore and copper ore. You setup your first furnace setup to automate copper and iron production.
You start to explore into electricity. You build steam engines, boilers, pipes and pumps. You start connecting coal suply lines to your boilers.
You discover research and start researching automation and logistics. You increase your mining production and build more smelters which are then used to produce resources for research.
Expanding more and more, your need for more resources increase. As does your production.
And then it hits you, there are sirens blaring, caution signs popping up in the map, you run over as fast as you can and are swarmed by bugs. The bugs kill you and half your base while your trying to produce weapons and ammo to fight back but it isnt enought, the bugs have already eaten your electricity production.
Your iron, coal and copper production soon follow in flames. You say ♥♥♥♥ it and turn the game off. That night while your trying to sleep, your mind is racing with what you did wrong, new smelting setups, more efficient power setups, new factory lines and automation designs.
The next day you spend as much time as you can trying to make your production as efficient as possible. You are attacked by bugs again, but this time, you dont quit. You start a new world, as soon as you have researched the bare essentials you research turrets.
You line your base with turrets and stock them with ammo. But then, a new type of bug emerges, one that can fire from range, they break into your base once again, but you have enough perimeter turrets to kill any scavengers. You then make a double layer of turrets around your base aided by layers of stone walls. You start mass producing ammo, and mass producing turrets. You then proceed to give the bugs the ♥♥♥♥ kicking they deserve.

This is a game that will test your limits, but make you keep coming back for more, make you recommend it to your mates. You will discover new things about this game every time you play, you will experiment with new technologies you have found, ♥♥♥♥ around with cars, tanks, flamethrowers, shotguns, rocket launchers.

You then discover how oil works, you discover a new fuel source, and go give them buggers freedom in exchange for their oil. You become the America of this alien world.

15/10 would become a yank again.



Factorio developer/s, congrats for your arrival on steam, you guys deserve it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Factorio is.. a incredible game!

In Minecraft the begin is always really fun, but once you have a diamond pickaxe getting resources is just a boring routine. In this game the start is quite simular, gather resources, wood, stone, coal, copper and iron. But after just a couple minutes you can already start automating the process.

Craft transport belts so the resources mined will travel to a furnace, then craft a inserter to move the resources in the furnace. Then once the smelted resource comes out make it go on another transport belt to go inside of an assembler that will craft things for you, expand your factory and create new things, and so on.

I have not played for too long but in the time I have there is still so much more that I can do. Plus you can play with friends in co-op or multiplayer.

If I had to rate this game it be a solid 9.0/10.0, it's definitely worth the €20. And if you're still not sure about buying it just download the free demo to see for yourself: https://www.factorio.com/demo/stable

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game stole 80 hours of my life. The story is, you seem to be an engineer who gets stranded on a remote planet. Your goal is to harvest material and refine them to build a communications satellite and mount a rescue. All without dying to the native creatures who will slowly adapt to remove your forign presence.

Its so simple its a little stupid, but designing the most efficent extraction and refining process will hasten your development of the technology that will ultimately save you in the end.

This game is currently in early access and is still in development. I would definitely like to see improved creature mechanics. Maybe development of a colonization effort. There are many possibilities that can be taken and this game has some amazing potential.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you have a creative mind, like working within a set of constraints that can be fudged around, and solving problems you created yourself while trying not to be devoured by squiggly alien pixels, this is for you. To me, personally, its kind of a modded out minecraft meets rollercoaster tycoon, meets tower defense, meets bacon. (there's no bacon in the game...but it FEELS like a good way to end my description)

A lot of the negative reviews (70 at the time of writing) are by people who obviously don't enjoy this kind of game to begin with, so take them with a grain of salt. Watch a letsplay or something, to make sure its for you.

This game is even better with a friend, due to the hilarity of combined goals, side projects that don't pan out, and getting utterly destroyed by the bugs as you're busy figuring out how to make your auto assemblers make green potions...

After 3 hours of game play, my buddy and I finally made green potions reliably.

9.5/10 - would waste another night making green potions

- 0.5 for the lack of actual bacon.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Another great resource managment game!

You start out with nothing but a tool, and you have to go around collect iron, wood, stone and copper. Then you smelt it in a primative furnace. After a bit of research, you can now build transport belts, inserteres and your automated factory is starting to take shape. Futher down the line you build trains to transport resources from distant mines and you go and fight the local annoying speices.
Then comes the time where everything is automated - you have robots flying all over the place, and lasers defending your base, and you may think that was it.

But it is not! Now its time to optimize, and you quickly reliaze that you are better of from scratch - so you start over, and 50 hours later, you feel like doing it again, because you keep learning new tricks to make a better factory... and that is Factorio!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Factorio is a game about crashing on an exotic planet and trying to craft materials for your way back home. Now, this may seem familiar and, fairly so, quite boring, but Factorio puts a nice spin on it:
In order to progress, you need to automate pretty much everything. The goal of your entire factory will be to create (4 different kinds of) science packs in order to progress in the tech tree, get new technologies which make your factory significantly more efficient and, eventually, reach the point at which you'll be able to launch rockets into space, in an effort to get back to your home planet.
Making science packs requires sophisticated chains of production, the ability to think ahead and a LOT of trial and error. On your journey to be able to unlock all tech, you'll also stumble upon some unfriendly fellas which will, if angered, start attacking your base. The more you anger them, the more pollution of yours reaches their base, the stronger they will get, so it's not a bad idea to prepare for this BEFORE they get too strong, you do this by either destroying their bases, building good enough defenses or simply not producing any pollution and going on greener ways.
All in all, Factorio has been in development for over 3 years now, being regularly updated by the developers. Before releasing the Steam version they have been hard at work at polishing and optimizing the game, so you can be pretty sure this won't be like your run-of-the-mill laggy, unfinished and bugged out Early Access game. Regular updates also contribute to the game staying bug-free while still adding content.

All in all, this is an inherently great game and I would recommend it to anyone remotely interested into the idea, as long as they're willing to commit a lot of time and effort into learning the game and how to make a working base.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The best early access game I've played hands down. Factorio is easy to learn and hard to master. Its addictive, rewarding, fun and has huge amounts of depth and freedom. After 45+ hours I'm still discovering new things.

This is only technically an early access game. Its stable, runs great, has plenty of content. As another (better) reviewer put it, think of it as a finished title with plenty of free dlc coming.

A top down, open world sci-fi survival and crafting game, its fairly unique and hard to summarise. It mixes many elements together. You will see bits of top down GTA games, Prison Architect, Minecraft's Tekkit mod, Command and Conquer, SimCity, The Martian and even Starship Troopers.

You are an astronaut crash landed on an alien planet. Your objective is to survive and extract enough natural resources to build a rocket to escape. At the start you dig up some materials by hand, until you have enough to create an automated mine. Then you gradually build up your production to meet your ever growing needs with more mines to extract ore, furnaces to smelt metals, conveyor belts to carry materials around and much, much more. As you raise your tech level you can build fancier machines, but to do this you need more advanced materials and so on.

There are native aliens that are hostile and attack your factory like the swarms of bugs from Starship troopers. You will need walls and turrets to defend from attacks. You will need to research and build armour, weapons and vehicles to go out and destroy hives that have grown to large. But to do this you will need to make sure your factory is processing enough raw materials to make the ammo and components you need.

The upgrade research path is sublimely balanced in the early-mid game. You are not punished for naive research choices while learning the ropes. As you get more adept at the game, it gives you a sense that your choices are having a real strategic impact but steers clear of following a linear formula. It does become a bit less important later on as you just try to get as much researched as possible.

Older systems and materials become obsolete as you move up the tech tree. For instance coal powered furnaces become obsolete as you research electric ones. But your conveyor system is designed to deliver coal to your furnaces. So you have to tweak your system bring it up to date and keep your processed iron flowing to the factories that need it.

For me there are three big reasons to give this a go:

1. There is always something to do. Theres always an assembly line to tweak to give better output, base improvements to make or exploring & combat to carry out. It never gets overwhelming but does give you that Just one more turn" addictiveness that you get with Civ.

2. Freedom. The terrain and resources are procedurally generated so no two factories/bases are the same and multiple styles and approaches work. One big base with mining and assembly all together? sure. Outpost bases each working on one specific resource and delivering its output by train? why not?

3. Its so satisfying. As I said at the start
hoursPlayed: you can pick anything up after laying it down so you are free to experiment with layouts and find out how each system or building works. But its hard to master. There are some really complex and smart logistics things you can do in the late game.\n\nYou are missing out on a gem if you don't give this a go. 10/10"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Factorio is the only game of this type that I have experienced and it might very well be it's own type of game. Therefore I don't know what to compare it too and will only say that it does what it does very well.

So what's the game about? It is a survival sandbox. You harvest a variety of ressources (wood, stone, copper ore, iron ore) to manufacture items, machines and buildings. Eventually, with these you are able to automate harvest of the ressources you previously had to manually gather. Everything in the game is automate-able, but, you'll have to carefully plan supply chains and layout of your manufacturing plant". So
date: how extensive can automation get in Factorio? Very extensive! You can buid automated trains that will follow a set-schedule to distant plants you'll have previously built to move around supply and feed your supply chains. For example
recommended: you import iron ore from a distant mining plant you've built and export machine gun ammunition to it so loaders/unloaders will automatically feed it to the defenses you've set-up over there. Why would you need defenses!? Well

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you have a creative mind, like working within a set of constraints that can be fudged around, and solving problems you created yourself while trying not to be devoured by squiggly alien pixels, this is for you. To me, personally, its kind of a modded out minecraft meets rollercoaster tycoon, meets tower defense, meets bacon. (there's no bacon in the game...but it FEELS like a good way to end my description)

A lot of the negative reviews (70 at the time of writing) are by people who obviously don't enjoy this kind of game to begin with, so take them with a grain of salt. Watch a letsplay or something, to make sure its for you.

This game is even better with a friend, due to the hilarity of combined goals, side projects that don't pan out, and getting utterly destroyed by the bugs as you're busy figuring out how to make your auto assemblers make green potions...

After 3 hours of game play, my buddy and I finally made green potions reliably.

9.5/10 - would waste another night making green potions

- 0.5 for the lack of actual bacon.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Factorio has a really interesting concept of gameplay. You build a Factory where your currently goal is to launch at least one rocket to space. But it is not easy as you might think. You need advanced technology to do so and many machines who deliver the parts. It is a long process where you can solve problems and make your factory efficient and automate everything.

I personaly like the challenge of the game and it makes you think.
But i think there is a downside at the moment when you reach the end game. You have a huge factory and automated everything and everything works fine. After that you dont really have something to do. Of course you can go and kill some more alien creatures but it lacks in endgame content. I am aware that the game is in early access and they will add more to it. I hope they will add something to the game which makes you want to play for longer and longer. Maybe something like a human colony you have to care. And diplomatic collaboration with aliens.

Considering everything i recommend the game. You will have at least 30 hours of gameplay if you like kind of games in this genre which makes the 20€ worth investing.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Factorio is.. a incredible game!

In Minecraft the begin is always really fun, but once you have a diamond pickaxe getting resources is just a boring routine. In this game the start is quite simular, gather resources, wood, stone, coal, copper and iron. But after just a couple minutes you can already start automating the process.

Craft transport belts so the resources mined will travel to a furnace, then craft a inserter to move the resources in the furnace. Then once the smelted resource comes out make it go on another transport belt to go inside of an assembler that will craft things for you, expand your factory and create new things, and so on.

I have not played for too long but in the time I have there is still so much more that I can do. Plus you can play with friends in co-op or multiplayer.

If I had to rate this game it be a solid 9.0/10.0, it's definitely worth the €20. And if you're still not sure about buying it just download the free demo to see for yourself: https://www.factorio.com/demo/stable

reviewText:
Early Access Review

See my total time up there? That's one session. When I'm done writing this, I'm probably going to pass out while listening to the sweet melody of the Inserters doing their Inserting and the Conveyers doing their Conveying.

This game is seriously addictive with an insane amount of stuff you can do to keep yourself occupied with. I haven't even touched the Campaign yet!

A great part of the game is that there is no singular way to tackle problems. If you run low on Copper, you can get some more to your base from a far-off location either by building a neat little train system, or build an insanely long Conveyer to get the raw materials to your Factory. You can even have a small army of robot helicopters fly it to you!

The factory itself...well...unless you spend hours/days planning it out, it's gonna get confusing. It's part of the beauty, though. When you look at what you've made and you think to yourself The f♥ck is going on?!".
Even with it looking so derped up

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I thought it's not worth so much cash, but I spent 11 hours straight ingame just after I bought it.

This game is addictive and so complex, that it will give you hours and hours of fun before you even figure out everything there is to build and unlock. After 11 hours I know I didn't.

That which can be a good thing to some, might be a bad thing to others though. The game IS very complex and managing everything will require quite the skill at both micro and macro management.

Fighting is pretty cheap though. You use turrets to defend and tanks to attack. That's it really. But the core of the game is building and maintaining supply routes. That's where the fun comes from! Especially in freemode.

Campaign is there, but, well... It's boring. Tutorials are a necessity and campaign probably helps with the steep learning curve.

Anyways - it sure is worth the attention. If you can't spend so much cash on this title, than at least wait for a promo.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If I had a child interested in computers like I was growing up, I would buy this game for them.

After they got hooked on it, I would explain to them that this is the best metaphor for becoming a systems engineer or a software developer that there is in game form. You start out hacking everything together manually in a very tedious manner, and every small automation early on feels like a big improvement. After you've been working there for a few years, you have your automated systems going like clockwork. Even still, you'll hem and haw over whether to automate this or that process. 'Do I use this enough to be worth it?', you'll think to yourself.  Over time, you'll learn new techniques that make your old attempts to do things look crude and sub-par. On the best days, you'll have those beautiful moments where you make a cup of tea and watch the universe unfold like it should without you lifting a finger. Then some variable changes akin to running out of ore or having giant bugs destroy your conveyor belts, and it's back to work.

If you like this game, you'll love working in tech, unless maybe you're not yet past that stage in your career when you tell people to turn their computer off and on again all day. Don't worry though, it gets better. Just keep reaching.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

My story of FactorioI stumble upon this game a couple of month before the Steamrelease and have a total game time of more than 120h ish of gameplay. I really enjoy the mechanics of the game, the logistical problem that needs to be solved and enemies that needs to be killed. As the developers say it is still an Early-Access but a very, in my opinion, stable game! It's a really well made sand-box game with no end-content (yet). After launching the satelite there are more optimisation to be done. More circuts to be made, steel to be smelted and solarlayouts to improve the electricity of the factorio. Reducing the smoke and polution.

At the time I'm writing this there is not yet a clear end-game content (as they are working on it) and is to be added to the game and I'm looking forward to it!

Recently i've played alot with mods and the modding community is greate! If you like more difficulty then what the original  game can offer? Then try out the mods! More bots? Mods! More aliens? Mods!

If you are like me, who like one of following
Factories
Automation
Big worlds with huge projects
Optimisation of factories.
Automation

Then this is the game for you.

* 10/10 - I would play this game again!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Awesome game. Well worth the money, espcially if there's some OCD in you. The game does feel complete for the most part. It's definitely stable and runs really well for me. There's just a few minor complaints I have with the game in it's current state.

My biggest complaint is just the late stages in the game where it requires way too much resources and time in order to get that rocket to launch. By way too much I mean it would have required me to spend 10+ more hours with my current factory (even longer if I tried to automate it better), just to reach 100% and then hit the launch button which is just a basic flight animation that doesn't benefit anything or really do anything. In the end, what's the point of all that effort in launching the rocket if there's no reason to?

I wish I could have better control over the inserters... being able to control which side of the belt they place items onto, and also be able to control their pickup and drop-off angle (like, instead of only 180 degree, allow it to do 90 degree pickup and drop-off). Maybe even be able to pick up or drop off from multiple directions. What's the point of smart inserters if they're not really smart?
EDIT: mods fix this issue.

I did find the alien bugs to be way too over-powered in the early and mid stages of the game (mainly the stationary worm spitting defenses), but as soon as I got the tank, they became no match for me. I just plowed through their massive bases like it was no big deal, and retreated to the gun turrets to repair the tank a bit, then went back to plow through some more, rinse and repeat until they're all dead. My only concerns were simply to not get stuck. The AI in this game is very basic though, they travel in a straight line and in the exact same spot each and every single time, so you really don't need to defend your entire base, just the areas each enemy bases send their bugs to. They also attack on a predictable schedule.

There are obstacles in the game which blend in way too much, especially when zoomed out, to the point where running your vehicles into stuff at least once is to be expected. Once you run into them, and you happen to not destroy your vehicle in the process, it'll make a health bar on that obstacle, so at least you'll be able to see it next time. Or you can magically destroy it with your weapons because... reasons.

You're able to zoom in way too much to the point where the textures are extremely muddy and gross, I'd actually prefer if they limited that a bit cuz I really don't want to see muddy textures like that.

I also wish the minimap was a bit smaller as it takes up a lot of my 4:3 screen. It'd be really nice if I could play the game on the primary monitor and have the entire map displayed on my secondary monitor.

It would also be nice to be able to build bridges and stuff onto the lakes... especially hydro lines and pipes.

None of my complaints are major, but they are worth mentioning. Aside from that, the game is perfect.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is THE stragtegic/logistics, game/simulator you never knew you wanted.

In fact, if you're a fan of RCT1&2, C&C, Sim City, micromanagement, 4x strategy, tower defense, indie games, challenging games, or general deep ponderings, you NEED Factorio. Don't shy away from Early access, this is a hugely fleshed-out title and is extremely stable and well-performing.

Factorio is deceptively simple at first, and soon escalates into something you have never seen or dreamed of before. That escalation escalates as you automate your automations. The gameplay quickly becomes deviously addictive, and you truly can work at your own pace.

Idle away and watch your machinations churn, or furiously work, build, collect, expand, and fight the alien natives. There are no penalties to play your way, and either a jumbled mess of pseudo-organised conveyors and machines or a perfectly planned and optimized meta-factory can both be successful.

As others have noted, if you are of the obsessive type, be warned: Factorio wants your waking hours, and some of what should be your sleeping hours as well.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Factorio is one of my favorite games. It's also one of the most polished and fun alphas I've ever seen. And it even have mods that make it crazier already!
I played it a lot outside of Steam, so don't be fooled. :)

Factorio is a Sandbox-Survival game where you play someone who crash-landed on an alien planet inhabited by a hostile race of primitive aliens that seem to, instead of going to the gym, simply breathe Carbon-Dioxide to get pumped up and angry before trying to steamroll your base.
What? Read on.

Initially, you'll have to gather resources manually in order to craft the tools you need for basic automation and basic research. You'll then start automating resource extraction, smelting, refining, production and research as you try to steer clear of the angry aliens. Eventually, you'll have automated trains loading up cargo on automated stations that's being automatically filled by automated extractors and smelteries. And as it reaches your main base, that train will be unloaded by automated cargo drones that will help you sort out your huge storage system and bring you whatever you need directly to your inventory.
And let's not forget about the construction bots that will automatically build blueprints you design. It's a simple, great feature that will make you do the Feel Good Man" face every time you build a new Solar Array.

Of course
recommended: build and progress as you wish. Make your designs as compact as you can or as large as you want. Design storage and sorting systems

(Personally when I first started playing with trains I completely forgot about the rest of the game and simply tried to weaponize them for a few hours.)

The game features a World Generator that really lets you fine-tune your experience. You can go for a game with passive and weak enemies filled with resources

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Factorio might just be the greatest game I have ever played, and that's pretty incredible considering it's still in early access. The game just launched on Steam yesterday, but I've been playing it for over a year as a member on their website and I've probably logged upwards of 300 hours already. The game challenges you to build a fully automated factory, starting with nothing but a furnace and a single mining drill. Your main goal is to progress through the tech tree, unlocking both features that will let you expand your factory and increase its efficiency, and features that will let you better defend against--and ultimately bring the fight to--the encroaching enemies who don't care for your pollutive presence on their land.

As a game, it's extremely well-paced. The progression is very smooth and concrete, both in your factory techs and your military techs. When you start building your first logistics and construction robots, or your first tier III assemblers, or when you don your first set of power armor and equip a shield modification, it feels like a big accomplishment. You will know you've come so far, yet there's still so much to improve upon.

But the tech tree isn't the only thing that keeps the pacing solid. The game forces you to balance action in fighting the enemies with the organization and construction of your base. So not all of your time is spent carefully planning out the next expansion you're going to install in your factory. The combat, like everything else, follows a progression. The biters (enemies) get increasingly harder as the game goes on, but their difficulty ramps up faster the more of them you kill. On the default settings, they're never overwhelming, but they're never really a breeze either until you hit the end of military techs, when you're running around on foot at 30mph with a shotgun that does 100 damage and fires 4 times per second.

Honestly there are only two complaints I have about this game in its current state. One is that the default resource generation is just not up to par. The devs have talked about changes they're going to make in the next major release to fix this, but in the game's current state it's just too easy. The resources are too frequent and the game generally gives you enough in your immediate starting area to at least make it to midgame without ever having to migrate your mining operations. This generally make the trains in the game, which are honestly a really cool feature, pretty useless. Endgame won't get you much futher than that either. I've had games where I was still on my second copper site (and you use a ton of copper in this game) by the time I launched my rocket. You can change the spawning settings when you start a new game, but the settings are quite arcane and rely on an understanding of Perlin noise to be effective. Like I said, though, the devs are going to be making improvements to this in the next major release (which sounds like it will be coming soon now that the Steam release has concluded), so I have something I'm looking forward to.

My second complaint is pretty niggling, and it's just that the car and tank controls are kinda weird to get your head around at first. Holding forward will drive you forward, but since your overview orientation is static, forward isn't forward from your perpsective, it's forward from the car's perspective. So if your car is facing the left edge of the screen, holding w will send you left. You definitely get used to them in time, but I still feel like turning with the car is too sensitive, and I'm constantly running into things.

Overall though, Factorio is the most feature-packed, brain intensive, epically-scoped action RTS sandbox city-building crafting game featuring automation that I've ever played, and hands-down the best game purchase I've ever made. It will give you tons of hours of fun, and I think it's well-worth trying it if you're even the least bit interested. So do I recommend this game?

Hell. Yes.

I Love this game, there's no easy way to put it...

I like the fact it's simple but at the same time brutally tricky, considering all the game really consists of is attempting to correlate input / output effect with a heavy leaning on logistic management, it manages to do so in a way that utterly absorbs me.

Such a silly simplistic concept but I've had so much intrigue (fun isn't quite the right word...) while playing. Utterly worth the asking price.

Buy this game if you enjoy:
-- resource management (aka settlers)
-- city build sims (aka cities skylines)
-- mico and macro organisation (aka no game that I'm aware of?)

Don't be fooled by the somewhat retro/simplistic graphics, underneath there is a game that will make your brain angrily happy.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've played this game since... well, a long-♥♥♥ time ago. I probably have 2000+ hours total. It falls into the same category of games as Dwarf Fortress-- a game I'll pick up now and again, burn days of time in, then put it down until I think about it again. That being said, please don't let my gaming habits reflect on how good this game is. Because it is -good.-

There are very few games that will keep me hooked for a long time. World of Warcraft, Dwarf Fortress, Rimworld, and a few others here and there are the only ones I've ever been able to consistently put 3-4 hours minimum a day into and never get bored. Factorio trumps nearly all of them with its near-infinite replayability and 0-infinity difficulty scaling.

There's always a belt to optimize, a production line to buff, or a biter nest that needs culling. Playing it Multiplayer makes it even more fun, if you can convince a friend to dump their life into a game. If you've got any kind of interest in factory-type games, or enjoy large networks of interacting dependent production lines, this is it. It is Anno on crack. It is Technic for grown-ups. Factorio distills all the unnecessary cruft from other similar games and keeps it straightforward-- but definitely not easy. Buy this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

In this game, you build a factory, so you can increase the size of your factory, to produce more stuff, to build a bigger factory, so you can mine and proccess more items, so you can craft some stuff to improve upon your factory, to make improving your factory easier...

It also has a campaign, and a combat system. I didn't really find these that interesting though.

I thought this game was pretty fun, and it reminded me of Prison Architect, which is a great game.

I started getting bored with this game at about the 20 hour point. I felt like it was getting a little repetitive, and I became pretty unmotivated to continue, as there weren't any really clear goals. As of right now, I've played for about 25 hours, and I probably won't play too much more of the game. That being said, for a $20 game, I think the game is well worth its price.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a neat kind of industrial process/flow game. Start with nothing, build a few machines to mine things and manually process materials, slowly building up material flows and processing and automation until you can finally have a factory that essentially runs itself. It's as simple or as complex as you want it to be and there's lots of options for neat setups much like you'll see people doing in minecraft. The trailer for this game is actually one of the better ones I've seen, as it boils down what the game is about into a one minute video.

The developers are first-time devs using an engine they're building themselves and they've done really well so far. They're keenly listening to customers and they also post weekly about their development and things they're learning/doing and their transitioning from a couple of guys working in a garage to a small game studio. Their blog provides a neat insight into game development and also clearly shows that they're making the kind of game they want to make, and doing it well.

If you enjoy stuff like Settlers 2 or SpaceChem or other games where the gameplay boils down to optimization and flows, going from simple setups and gradually making them more complex and intricate and efficient, then you'll enjoy this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Factorio is simply amazing, and it is only getting better.   Just look at the amount of time played by some of the reviewers, or of friends on your friend list who own it.  In terms of value - I could only dream of living in a world where developers put this amount of time, effort, community collaboration, and content into their work.  In this day and age where quality early access games are few and far between, and microtransactions filled free to play games domintate the market in terms of sheer numbers, drowing out smaller and newer developers, it is such an amazing refreshing feeling to see a game like Factorio.

Factorio is a sandbox openworld building game where your goal is to automate everything.  It shares a similar concept with many games, in such that each resource requires a combination of resources that come before it to create.  You start small, but believe you me, you get big!  Towards the end of the tech trees when your factory gets really big, it is truly astounding that it actually functions and that YOU actually made it!  It reminds me a lot of lego's in a sense, and also the human body, in that each little part does its function and as a whole they create this amazingly complex machine.  You actually learn a lot while playing it too, in an engineer'ish type way. Sometimes changing just one thing creates this huge butterfly effect, and rather than reverting it back, figuring out why and making it work is so much more fun.  With multiplayer (which I will talk about a little more down below) you can see in real time how people look at the same problem and solve it in different ways, which I find fascinating.

There are a million ways to play this game, but personally I (and I know so many others do too, as this is one of the core concepts that draws people like us to this genre) love figuring out how to make each little contraption work at the most efficient rate I can.  I also loved making my first factory as symmetrical as I could, because it just looked so cool.  Copper on the left, iron on the right in the exact pattern.  Oil up the middle with some green chips on each side just because it looked cool!

If you have even the slightest bit of OCD this game will turn it on overdrive, but in a bizzarly fun way...I can't really explain it, just trust me xD

The developer is constantly adding to the game, and listens to the community feedback, which is in my opinion neccesary in 2016.  There is so much more I could say about this game, but I will just add this one final and AWESOME end note....It already has *PERFECTLY* working multiplayer, which makes it just THAT much better.  These are my absolute favorite types of games, and I have always wanted a good open sandbox game to play with my friend(s), and now I have one.

If you are even considering buying this game for whatever reason, do yourself a favor buy it.    These are exactly the types of dev's we need in the gaming world today, our support means everything!

*An easier way to use muliplayer is being added in one of the next updates, but as of now just use the program evolve" which allows your to share an IP address with whoever you party with
date: and just join a party with whoever you want to play with."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

How Toyota Became the World's Best Manufacturer?

they played Factorio.

- 14 Toyota(Factorio) Way Principles -
Principle 1. Base your management decisions on a long-term philosophy,
even at the expense of short-term financial goals.
Principle 2. Create a continuous process flow to bring problems to the surface.
Principle 3. Use “pull” systems to avoid overproduction.
Principle 4. Level out the workload (heijunka).
Principle 5. Build a culture of stopping to fix problems, to get quality right
the first time.
Principle 6. Standardized tasks and processes are the foundation for continuous
improvement and employee empowerment.
Principle 7. Use visual control so no problems are hidden
Principle 8. Use only reliable, thoroughly tested technology that serves your
people and processes
Principle 9. Grow leaders who thoroughly understand the work, live the
philosophy, and teach it to others.
Principle 10. Develop exceptional people and teams who follow your company’s
philosophy.
Principle 11. Respect your extended network of partners and suppliers by
challenging them and helping them improve.
Principle 12. Go and see for yourself to thoroughly understand the situation
(genchi genbutsu).
Principle 13. Make decisions slowly by consensus, thoroughly considering
all options; implement decisions rapidly (nemawashi).
Principle 14. Become a learning organization through relentless reflection
(hansei) and continuous improvement (kaizen).

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Rating: 9/10
I bought this game over a year ago from the developers website and have played this game around 80 hours total. The goal in the game is to build an automated factory. You start of small using the resources in your immediate vicinity, however after some time expansion is necessary to get more distant resources, while fighting enemies.

The fun in this game is trying to create the necessary items, with your always increasing factory, for your research and other items. Most of the time is spent working on how to get all the resources and items to the correct place in your factory. At the start you can only transport your goods on your avatar or with belts, but in the middle late game you also get the option of trains and robots. For me the most fun was designing a train network for transporting resources from distant outposts to my main base.

My only negative point about the game is the RTS element. The fighting was fun when I first started playing the game, it’s however quite easy late game and repetitive.
Also the game does have quite a steep learning curve, which can be a deal breaker for some people. It can take quite some time designing and redesigning before you are able to make an proper factory, however I personally loved that.

All in all I give this game a 9/10 and would definitely recommend it to anyone who likes a to build a large and awesome base ;). Also playing coop is awesome.
