reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've been playing Factorio off and on for the past couple years after seeing an article about the game on Rock Paper Shotgun. Immediately, the game peaked my interest but I was sad to see that the game was only in alpha at the time. I was surprised at how polished the game felt (even a few years ago!) and spent probably 20+ hours with it my first time through.

It's obvious that the developers love their game and, although I feel development has been on the slow, the game has gotten progressively better. I've revisted the game several times in the past few years mostly after learning about the awesome modding community. It is comprised of die-hard fans of the game and you can find anything from game-changing mods to subtle changes for personal preference.

As it stands, the game is basically sandbox and freeplay only. I kind of hoped that a campaign would present itself sooner but so far it is not much. It's not such a big deal because freeplay is really fun and has a lot of replayability with the mods.

My biggest gripe with the game are the aliens". I like the idea of building a mining operation that must be defended but the combat
recommended: is not good. Gun play is really weak and invading enemies really don't have a huge impact if you know how to deal with hives before pollution spreads. Typically
hoursPlayed: I just play on "peaceful" mode where enemies only attack if you attack them because I prefer to focus on automation and problem-solving and not have to invest time or effort into the combat. I truly hope that they'll make combat more exciting or introduce different modes instead of "peaceful" or "hostile" such as a mode where combat is the main focus or objectives must be taken to win

4/5 Stars!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Short version: It's a puzzle (this makes sense as you play it) and resource management game with some very light combat thrown in. It's an awesome game if you want a non-combat challenge that pushes you to think.

Long version: Factorio is definitely not for every one. Things not to expect from Factorio: rewarding/challenging combat, in game help on what the best layouts are (there's a reason for this), easy diffuculty curve, and fun if you're not into building/maintaining networks that can be grossly complex (seriously, you won't have fun if you don't enjoy building logistic networks because that is the focus of the game).

Look at the trailer, now realize that the layout you see there is not an exageration of what's needed as you progress through the tech. Lets break it down from the begining on what the crafting tree is like and it might shed a bit of light on that thought:

Coal + Iron ore + (inserted into) Smelter = Iron plate. Same thing with copper. Then: Iron plate -> Crafted into -> Iron gear, Copper Plate -> Crafted into -> Copper cable. Copper Cable + Iron plate -> Crafted into -> Electronic circuit. Iron gear + Electronic circuit + Iron plate -> Crafted into -> Inserter.

Each time you see (crafted into) you can craft this at a machine called an assembler that will make it for you so long as it is powered and has access to all of the correct compenents, and with the inserter created, you can now move items from a chest, smelter, or assembler to another container or onto a conveyor belt.

The goal of all of the above? Trying to automate as much of it as possible, even though your character can create all of the above items mentioned, he can only create one thing at a time, and when you need at least three inserters for a single smelter (one for coal, one for ore, and one for the output) you'll soon realize making it all by hand slows the game down significantly.

Keep in mind that the resources you need will NOT be conviently placed and you will HAVE to figure out how to get resources from point A to B... and then C, and then A1, B2, and C5 (because a basic resource can be used in multiple recipes, it will need to split into different allocation lines). Then, when the resources in a particular spot has run out, it's time to pack up all that equipment in that area and move it somewhere else and then reconnect it back to the network.

Now the combat is very basic (because that's not the focus of the game). If you have a gun and ammo, you mouse in the general direction of the nasty critter you want dead and hold down space bar. Otherwise, you make gun/laser turrets to protect your network (you will need to as depending on resource locations, networks can get mas+sive) while you're not there. Then when you're ready to assualt a particular nasty nest of the beasties, create a tank and blast them to hell.

But that's it, there is no RPG elements like gaining experience, nor is there a reward for killing all of them on the map. The game does become a bit too easy if you don't have the creatures attacking you as then there's no reason to waste resources (and more importanly assembly line space) on creating defences.

The point of all this is to make it painfully obvious that if you don't like the sound of making optimal configurations for logistic networks, then pass on this game. Otherwise, take a look at the demo if it's still available.

I haven't even tried multiplayer yet, but have had this game for quite some time before the steam keys were released. It's an awesome game and would highly recommend it to any one who's interested.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Factorio is a game primarily about solving very complex design challenges with a vast array of tools at your disposal. Those with a love of micromanagment, complex problem solving and (to a lesser extent) spreadsheets will find this game to be a finely crafted gem. Its depth and breadth unrivaled by any competitor.


That being said, if you're not the into problem solving for the joy of problem solving, Factorio can also be a rather bland (and grindy) puzzle game with an anticlimactic endgoal.


While not a game to be recommended to everyone, it's one of the rare, highly polished exemplars of what an indie/early-access team can create with a clear vision and unwavering dedication.



(Note: I owned the game pre-steam, so my playtime will likely be dozens of hours lower than reality.)

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nGreat resource management, technology building simulator.  Remember those resource fields you had to defend in Red Alert? Yeah, there are fields here too that are just as important.  Remember the last game you played that technology built upon itself (Civilazation)? Yep, that's here too.  How about building a working, moving model that actually does something (Sim City)?  Yep...in factory form.  Now toss in some aliens that like to eat both you and your creations to give you incentive.  That's factorio in a nutshell.  Well worth the purchase in my opinion.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nOh i have no idea how much i've actually played this game before it hit steam.  All i nkow is you need to put Raymond Scott's 'Powerhouse' on permanent loop and go insane building the most elaborate factory known on any planet.  The machinery needs to be fed and the guns prepared to keep the aliens at bay.  So what if you're polluting their planet and enraging them?  You have technology on your side!  It takes no effort to become obsessive about laying out the perfect working system, but it takes tremendous fussiness to actually make it happen.  Haven't had this much fun building a factory chain since modded Minecraft became a thing.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For those that have not yet played Factorio, do not let the number of hours played fool you, due to the fact I have been playing the non-Steam version for a long time, and have easily played hundreds of hours. If you already have Factorio, it is likely you are not even reading this, or forgotten that most early backers probably have a Steam Key Available.

The basic principle of the game is simple, you just have to build a bunch of assembly lines to get back into space. There's just one small detail, and by small I mean relentless creatures that do not take too kindly to your existence. You will find yourself mining ore, stone, wood, and drilling for oil to supply an ever increasing complex production chain of goods. All while researching new methods in which to build, new materials to create, and defend yourself from the locals".

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nFactorio is a rare game in a class all it's own. I've barely scratched the surface of this game and it scares me how brilliant it is. reviewText:
Early Access Review

Buy game at 10 PM
Don't check clock until it's 4:30 AM
Sun comes up
It's 8 AM
Well, time to get some sleep

(True story)

But anyway, one of the best $20 I've ever spent. If you're a man that enjoys making things more efficient, then get this game. It will intellectually satisfy you as you figure out how to logistically move the materials for these complex recipes around. And you will feel good when you analyze your chain and figure out that you can make it smoother by giving this factory a faster grabbing arm.

It's a great example of design over graphics

This game is amazing, the sheer scale of the factories you can build, the complexity and all the moving parts are mind boggling. There really is no limit about how big you can build your factory. How far your trains can go and how much you can pollute the planet (Somehow more pollution leads into more bullet consumption).

I don't think there are any other games out there right now that match up with this scale. And I'm sure none of them can run as smooth. This game is a must buy if you enjoy tower defense, automation, puzzles and wiping out alien civilizations with the power of smog.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Disclaimer: At the time of this writing I haven't completed the win condition" yet. Yet.

Factorio is a game for which I have been waiting a long time. It can be a bit confusing to get started but if you can get past the somewhat bumpy start (the tutorial helps with this but I still had to do some outside research on some mechanics) there is a very addicting game waiting for you.
The premise is that you are crashlanded on an alien planet and you have to build a rocket to get off. The start certainly sounds simple. "I'll get some coal and some drills and some smelters and smelt iron ore into iron plates!" Things are going great. And then the game expands on that concept and expands on it again and what you end up with is somewhat of a logistic puzzle game involving transport of materials
recommended: and trying to balance all of your resources between everything you are using them for. Then the iron vein you were mining will run dry and you'll have to find a new patch and figure out either how to hook it in to your existing factory or tear down what you have and rethink how you were doing some things.\nAnd all of this is made much more interesting by the research tree which

reviewText:
Early Access Review

OK, so the first thing I need you to do is stop reading the review and go watch the two trailers above. They get the appeal of the game across better than I could.

Done that? No you haven't. But if you had, you'd already know that Factorio is like a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ lovechild of SpaceChem and Minecraft, raised in a ménage à trois with Transport Tycoon. You start out and it's just like any other survival game - click for resources, use resources to build things. Except that the first thing you'll build is a mining drill, which gathers resources for you but needs to be fed with coal. Then you'll probably design a system that handles the coal-feeding automatically. Then you'll build an electrical network, so that (almost) the only thing that needs coal any more is the boilers. Eventually, you'll even build robots to build things for you! Over the course of the game, you'll create a gigantic factory dedicated to the production of a single rocket to get you off the planet.

Or, you know, stay down there and build up a factory that launches not just one rocket, but one rocket per second. Or acts as a Turing machine. (Seriously, check Youtube.)

Of course, while you're doing this you'll be fending off attacks from the biters - insectile natives who get quite, well, bitey when they run across your pollution. They gradually get stronger over the course of the game, so they stay a threat until the endgame. The endgame then consists of using your superior technology to gleefully exterminate them, take their stuff, and use it to research your rocket prior to building it. They can be made peaceful in the game start options if you'd rather just build, but where's the fun in that?

Yes, this is an early access game. But it's been under development and in open paid alpha for going on five years now, and it is absolutely worth your $20/€20 in its current state. It's essentially bug-free (except for the biters), it has hundreds of hours of gameplay, and the devs are consistently adding new features. There are rough edges, but they're the sort of thing that's easy to fix given enough time. The biggest issue is probably the user interface, which isn't particularly discoverable - you'll probably need to check online to see how to use some of the things you can build. The graphics are also quite lo-fi and muddy"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Dont let the playtime fool you. I have had it  10/2014. Best strategy, Base building, Sandbox IMO. I have a few suggestions to anyone on the fence. The game is great, stable, and easy to get hooked on. Installing mods is very easy and expand the game even further. There are many options and console commands to help you, and make the game play the way you like it. Crank up the biters to max and create a massive invasion/military factory or set them to peaceful if you just want to build.

The game is well worth the price, but if you add in the modding community its easily worth 3x as much. The left ALT key! Also watch those youtubers like Steejo, Arumba, and Negative root. When you beat the game add some mods in like BOBS"
date: "5DIMS" or "Yukis" mods or if your really crazy "Shadows Mega Mod Pack"\n\nThis community has been one of the best ones I have had the pleasure of being part of I am truely happy that they are on steam FINALLY! I hope you enjoy this game as much as I did."

It's also pretty well optimised so I can get a solid 60fps on my rather crappy laptop.

If you like the look of the game, or this style of game, please  buy it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Factorio is easily one of the best games of recent memory, and has the quality and polish of a much more experienced team. It combines base building, resource gathering, crafting, (tower?) defense, and puzzle elements to create one of the most satisfying early access experiences of all time, and I'm excited to see where to goes from here.

If development on Factorio were to be suddenly stopped right now, then I'd still think that it's worth the money. It's just that good.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nAt the time of writing this review, Steam says I've put less than an hour into playing this game. The truth is that I've been playing this game a lot before it came to Steam. I originally paid $40 for it and it's been worth every penny. Based on my saved games data, I've put in around 100 hours of playtime and yet there is still so much more to do! Don't let the Early Access label taint your judgment in this game's case. There is a great deal of content and depth in its current state, and the fact that they're not even finished with it just makes its future even more exciting.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Insanely addictive strategic building game, nostalgic C&C like graphics. Would reccomend for anyone who likes old-school strategy games and logistic-building games (Starcraft merged with TransportTycoon) as it marries the best of both together in a unique title.

Addictive - High gameplay hours and replayability.
Macro - Havent yet found any sort of build limit, map limit or enemy limit. Its all as endless as you would like it to be.
Research and Character Progression - Upgrades for buildings armor and weapons.
Building - Intuitive, easy to build logistics systems allowing for practically limitless creative solutions.
PvE - Constantly respawning, multiplying and evolving enemy alien colonies keep the game challenging.
Pollution - The more you pollute the local atmosphere, the more it upsets the locals.
Vehicles - Go cruising the infinite world in cars or tanks after creating your stronghold.
Multiplayer - Can connect over 60000 players to a single multiplayer game.

If you are interested enough to like what you saw of the gameplay and graphics style in the preview video, just buy it, you probably will not regret it!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I was hesitant to get the game because of the pixel graphic style, but the simple graphics apparently allowed the developer to really add a tremendous amount of gameplay!

If you were the type of RTS player that liked to turtle and build a nuke to hit everyone and win.... this is your game!   All about efficiency, tech tree leveling, resource harvesting and distrobution, and finally attack and defense of all this from the aliens!

Definitely worth the 20 bucks  I paid for it.   I'm interested in seeing how the developer keeps evolving the game.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is one of those games where you just build things, because its fun and it looks rewarding. I needed 10 walls, I could have just mined it myself but I ended up building this big factory for it. I took my 10 walls and let it do couple thousand more because that's what you do in this game. You just build and optimize since you have good time doing that.

You can automate the base very nicely. Like mine some iron, melt it and make ammo from it. Then transport it by belts near the turret and add arm that reloards the turret. So you end up with bases that just run by itself. See enemies attack, turrets shoot them, arm reloads the turret, factories produce more ammo... it all looks very nice to me.

For early access this game is the better ones. There is already a lot of things to build. For me there is some minor issues, like building the railroads. It feels clunky, I found from their blog that they are looking into making it better. The examples I saw looks very promising. It really feels like the developement team is active on this game. The blog updates frequently with news and things they are working on.

It's definitely going to be one of those games I come back again and again.
